Here, bs and iodepth are performance testing parameters.

Disk performance testing

Before testing, make sure that the following conditions are met:

   the disk is nonbootable;
   there is no load on the disk from the operating system.

   When these conditions are met, the IOPS measurement results must correspond to the following values:

    Type of testing  Result, IOPS 
       
    Read/write in blocks of 4 KB in 32 threads  Complies with SLA   
    Read/write in blocks of 8 KB in 32 threads  At least 75% of SLA 
    Read/write in blocks of 16 KB in 32 threads  At least 50% of the SLA 

Test the disk.

   Windows
   Linux


   To measure IOPS when reading and writing, use the DiskSpd or FIO utilities.


   The measurement results obtained using DiskSpd and FIO may differ. DiskSpd is a utility created and recommended by Microsoft for testing disks in Windows OS.


   DiskSpd

   Run the command prompt as an administrator.
   Create a temp directory and an empty file of at least 10 GB in size:

            md C:\temp
      fsutil file createnew C:\temp\test.bin 10485760000

   Download the utility and unpack to the required directory.
   Go to the amd64 directory of the unpacked utility.
   Run the command diskspd with parameters corresponding to the type of test:

      w — percentage of write operations, w0 for the reading test, w100 for the recording test;
      b — block size in bytes.

      Detailed description of all command parameters diskspd — in official documentation.

      Random write test in blocks of 4 KB:

                  diskspd Suw b4K o1 t32 r w100 C:\temp\test.bin > C:\temp\random_write_results.txt

      Random reading test in blocks of 4 KB:

                  diskspd Suw b4K o1 t32 r w0 C:\temp\test.bin > C:\temp\random_read_results.txt

   FIO

   Download and install FIO.
   Run the fio command with the parameters corresponding to the type of test:

      rw — randread or randwrite.
      bs — block size.
      filename — name of the test file.
      rate_iops — IOPS target value (optional). Use this parameter to get a more accurate latency value when testing the IOPS target value.

      Detailed description of all command parameters — in FIO documentation.

      Random write test in blocks of 4 KB:


         Do not specify the name of the file with the necessary data in the filename parameter! During write tests, the contents of this file will be overwritten.

         PowerShell
         Command line


                  fio `
            namerandwrite `
            iodepth32 `
            rwrandwrite `
            bs4k `
            direct1 `
            size10G `
            numjobs1 `
            runtime240 `
            group_reporting `
            filenameC:\Users\ADMIN\test


                     fio ^
            namerandwrite ^
            iodepth32 ^
            rwrandwrite ^
            bs4k ^
            direct1 ^
            size10G ^
            numjobs1 ^
            runtime240 ^
            group_reporting ^
            filenameC:\Users\ADMIN\test


      Random reading test in blocks of 4 KB:

         PowerShell
         Command line


                  fio `
            namerandread `
            iodepth32 `
            rwrandread `
            bs4k `
            direct1 `
            size10G `
            numjobs1 `
            runtime240 `
            group_reporting `
            filenameC:\Users\ADMIN\test


                  fio ^
            namerandread ^
            iodepth32 ^
            rwrandread ^
            bs4k ^
            direct1 ^
            size10G ^
            numjobs1 ^
            runtime240 ^
            group_reporting ^
            filenameC:\Users\ADMIN\test


   To measure IOPS when reading and writing, use the FIO utility.


   This technique is only applicable for testing partitions with the file system ext2, ext3, ext4 or xfs.


   Update the package list:

            sudo apt update

   Install FIO:

            sudo apt install fio

   Run the fio command with the parameters corresponding to the type of test:

      rw — randread or randwrite.
      bs — block size.
      filename — the name of the test file. The user must have read and write permissions to the filename to run the tests.
      rate_iops — IOPS target value (optional). Use this parameter to get a more accurate latency value when testing the target IOPS value.

      Detailed description of all command parameters — in FIO documentation.

      Random write test in blocks of 4 KB:


         Do not specify the name of the file with the necessary data in the filename parameter! During write tests, the contents of this file will be overwritten.


                  fio \
            namerandwrite \
            ioenginelibaio \
            iodepth32 \
            rwrandwrite \
            bs4k \
            direct1 \
            size512M \
            numjobs1 \
            runtime240 \
            group_reporting \
            filename/home/user/test

      Random reading test in blocks of 4 KB:

                  fio \
            namerandread \
            ioenginelibaio \
            iodepth32 \
            rwrandread \
            bs4k \
            direct1 \
            size512M \
            numjobs1 \
            runtime240 \
            group_reporting \
            filename/home/user/test


If, when all conditions are met, the test results do not match the specified values, contact technical support.

Delete the large test files to free up disk space after testing is completed and the results are processed. Quotas and limits on the quantity and size of disks are given in the Quotas and Limits article.

title: Creating VM
data:
In Cloud Servers, you can create virtual machines through your management console, OpenStack CLI or Terraform. To create a VM using Terraform, use the VM creation instructions in the Terraform section.

Before starting work

Register on the VK Cloud platform.
Verify that the payment account balance is positive and quotas are sufficient to create the target configuration of the virtual machine.

Available OS

The VK Cloud team has prepared images of some operating systems. The list of readymade images is available in your management console in the window for creating a new instance.

If necessary, you can import an OS image by yourself.

Create a VM



The available fields may differ for different operating systems.





Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Click the Create instance or Add button.
Set VM parameters:
     Name of virtual machine: use only Latin letters, numbers, or special characters , _, and ..
     Category of virtual machine: select the flavor of the VM. For more information, see Cloud Servers service overview.
     Type of virtual machine: select the preset VM configuration. For more information, see Cloud Servers service overview.
     Availability zone: select the data center where the VM will be launched.
     Number of machines in configuration: specify the required number of VM.
     Disk size: specify the required VM disk size in gigabytes.
     Disk Type: select one of the values — HDD, SSD or HighIOPS SSD. For more information, see Cloud Servers service overview.
     Operating system: select the operating system version or previously created image.
     Tags: if necessary, specify the tag for the VM or create a new one.
Click Next step.
Configure the VM connection to the network:
   Network: select an existing network or create a new one. Depending on the choice of network type, the list of available fields will change.
   SDN: select a virtual network management system. Resources created in networks of different SDNs will be accessible to each other only when using floating IPs. The option is available if a new network is created for the VM.
   Subnet address: the option is available if a new network is created for the VM.
   Use configuration disk: enable the option if you need to automatically configure a network on a virtual machine when there is no DHCP server on the network. The option is enabled automatically if a network with DHCP disabled is selected, including the external network (extnet).
   DNSname: specify the DNS name for the VM. For more information, see Private DNS. The option is not available, if the external network is selected (extnet).
   Virtual machine key: select a key for SSH connection or create a new one.

      If you select Create a new key, save the suggested key file .pem after the virtual machine creation is completed.

   Firewall settings: select the appropriate security groups.

      To connect via SSH, add the group ssh or ssh+www. For more information about configuring network access rules, see Managing firewall rules.

   (Optional) Assign external IP: enable the option and specify the IP to be able to connect to the VM from the Internet. The option is available if the VM is on a network with an Internet connection. The option is enabled and automatically configured the IP address if the VM is located on an external network (extnet).

   (Optional) Link a domain to an external IP: enable the option and specify a domain to link the FQDN to the external IP. An Arecord for the selected IP will be added to the DNS. The option is available if the Assign external IP option is enabled.


      You cannot link an external IP to a domain that matches the CNAME record of the DNS zone. In this case, the VM will be created, but the Arecord will not be added.


   Enable monitoring: enable to use monitoring tools.

Click Next step.

If necessary, enable the Use Backup option and specify settings.
Click Create instance.
Wait for the VM to be created. This process may take some time. When the creation is completed, a page with VM characteristics and connection instructions will open.




Get ready to work with the OpenStack CLI:

   Enable twofactor authentication.
   Activate API access.
   Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Collect the data:

   Get a list of available VM types and save the required flavor_ID:

            openstack flavor list

   Get a list of available VM images and save the required image_ID:

            openstack image list

   Get a list of security groups:

            openstack security group list

       To create a Linux VM and connect to it via SSH, save the security_group_ID of the group ssh or ssh+www.
       To create a Windows VM and connect to it via RDP, save the security_group_ID of the group rdp or rdp+www.

      For more information about configuring network access rules, see Managing firewall rules.

   Get a list of available networks and save the required network_ID:

            openstack network list

      If the extnet network is selected, an external IP address will be automatically assigned to the virtual machine.
      If a private network is selected, then a floating IP address can be assigned to the virtual machine after creation.

   Get a list of available key pairs and save keypair_name:

            openstack keypair list

      To create a new key pair:
         Generate a key:

                        sshkeygen q N ""

         Upload the key:

                        openstack keypair create publickey ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub type ssh

Create a boot disk:

      openstack volume create rootvolume size 10 image  availabilityzone MS1 bootable

Create a VM:

      openstack server create
                           volume
                           network  \
                           flavor  \
                           keyname  \
                           availabilityzone MS1

   After creating a VM, information about it will be displayed. Find the adminPass field and copy its value. You will need it to sign in to the server via the VNC console.

Check the status of the created VM:

      openstack server list

   The created machine should appear in the list of available VMs and have the status ACTIVE.



Some features of creating a VM via the CLI:

If you do not specify an availability zone, a random one will be selected.
If you do not specify a disk, an “ephemeral disk” will be created (with restrictions).

What's next?

See the ways to connect to Linux VM or Windows.
Learn how to work with VM.
description: How to create and configure a VM.

title: Connecting to Linux VM
data:
The recommended way to connect to a Linux VM is via SSH using a key pair.

1. Check ability to connect via SSH

To connect via SSH, an SSH server must be running on the virtual machine. On Linux virtual machines created in VK Cloud, the OpenSSH server is installed and started by default.

Before connecting, make sure that the following conditions are met:

the virtual machine is running and the OS boot process has finished;
remote access via SSH protocol (TCP port 22) is allowed in the VM network settings — add ssh security group;
the VM has an external (“floating”) IP address available for connection.


   The external IP address of the VM can be viewed in management console VK Cloud in the section Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.


Instead of an external IP address, you can use the fully qualified domain name of the virtual machine (FQDN). Properly configured DNS records are required to connect using a fully qualified domain name.



VK Cloud provides DNS servers to which you can delegate your domain.



The virtual machines that were created from the FreeBSD and Bitrix images offered by the VK Cloud platform do not support working with an external extnet network. To connect via SSH to such a VM, it is necessary that it is on a private network with DHCP enabled.

If SSH connection to the VM is not possible or unavailable, use the VNC console.

2. Prepare credentials

To connect to the VM via SSH, you need to know the operating system account name and password.

Set a password to log in to the OS. Write down the account name and password.

If the password has been lost, reset or restore it.

3. Check for key pair

To connect to a VM over SSH using a key pair, it is necessary that the public key is stored on the virtual machine in the file ~/.ssh/authorized_keys, and the file with the private key is located on the computer from which the connection is being made.

If the VM was created on the VK Cloud platform:

the public key was saved on the VM automatically;
when selecting the option Create a new key, the private key in the file with the extension .pem was downloaded to the computer from which the VM was created.

If one or both of the keys from the pair are lost, follow the recovery instructions.

4. Connect to VM



Linux/macOS
Windows 10/11
Windows 7/8



(Optional) Configure access rights to the key file:

      chmod 400

Run the command in the terminal.

   To connect by IP address:

            ssh i  @

   To connect by a fully qualified domain name:

           ssh i  @

If this is the first connection to the VM, a confirmation request will appear:

            The authenticity of host '213.219.212.130 (213.219.212.130)' can't be established.
      ECDSA key fingerprint is SHA256:aYZIWs9N6KRtfFOuic6eoWcluhSp6+jha/DSBgd9McI.
      Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)?

      Type yes in the terminal and press Enter.


      The first time you connect to a VM created from a Bitrix VK Cloud image, a request to change the password for the root user will appear in the console. Enter the current bitrix password and enter the new password twice.


(Optional) Configure access rights to the private key file:

   Open the properties of the private key file .pem.
   Go to the Security tab and click Advanced. The Advanced Security Settings window opens.
   Click the button Disable inheritance and in the window that opens, select Remove all inherited permissions from this object.
   In the Advanced Security Settings window, click Add.
   In the window that opens, click Select the subject and specify the Windows OS user on whose behalf the command prompt for connecting to the VM will be launched.
   Confirm the changes by sequentially clicking OK in the open settings windows.

Run the command in the command prompt.

   To connect by IP address:

            ssh i  @

   To connect by a fully qualified domain name:

           ssh i  @

If this is the first connection to the VM, a confirmation request will appear:

            The authenticity of host '213.219.212.130 (213.219.212.130)' can't be established.
      ECDSA key fingerprint is SHA256:aYZIWs9N6KRtfFOuic6eoWcluhSp6+jha/DSBgd9McI.
      Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)?

     Type yes in the command prompt and press Enter.


      The first time you connect to a VM created from a Bitrix VK Cloud image, a request to change the password for the root user will appear in the console. Enter the current bitrix password and enter the new password twice.


In Windows 7/8, use the PuTTY application to connect via SSH.

Install PuTTY.
Create a private key file in PuTTY Private Key Files format:

   Launch the PuTTYgen application that comes with PuTTY.
   In the Conversions menu, click Import Key and in the window that opens, select the private key file .pem.
   Click Save private key.
   In the window that opens, select a directory, enter a file name, check that the .ppk extension is specified in the File type field, and click Save.

Add the private key file .ppk to Pageant:

   Launch the Pageant application that comes with PuTTY.
   Rightclick on the Pageant icon on the taskbar.
   In the context menu, select Add key.
   Select the private key file .ppk created in the previous step.

Run PuTTY:

   In the Host Name (or IP address) field enter the external IP address of the virtual machine or its full domain name. Specify the port 22 and the connection type SSH.
   Open the item in the tree on the left Connection → SSH → Auth.
   Set the checkbox Allow agent forwarding.
   In the Private key file for authentication field, select the private key file .ppk.
   Click Open.
   If this is the first connection to the VM, confirm it in the window that appears.
   In the terminal window that opens, you will be prompted to enter the OS user name.
   Enter the VM operating system user name. As a result, a connection to the server should be established.


      The first time you connect to a VM created from a Bitrix VK Cloud image, a request to change the password for the root user will appear in the console. Enter the current bitrix password and enter the new password twice.


If you could not connect to the VM via SSH, use the instructions from the article Network in a Linux VM.
description: How to connect to a Linux VM via SSH.

title: Connecting to Windows VM
data:
The recommended way to connect to a Windows VM is via the RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol).

1. Check ability of connecting via RDP

Make sure that the following conditions are met:

the virtual machine is running and the OS boot process has finished;
remote access via RDP protocol (TCP port 3389) is allowed in the VM network settings;
the VM has an external (“floating”) IP address available for connection.


   The external IP address of the VM can be viewed in management console VK Cloud in the section Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.


Instead of an external IP address, you can use the fully qualified domain name of the virtual machine (FQDN). Properly configured DNS records are required to connect using a fully qualified domain name.



VK Cloud provides DNS servers to which you can delegate your domain.



If RDP connection to the VM is not possible or unavailable, use the VNC console.

2. Prepare credentials

To connect to a VM via RDP, you need to know the operating system user name and password.

Set password to log in to the OS. Write down the username and password.

If the password has been lost, reset or recovery it.

3. Connect to VM



Linux
macOS
Windows



In Linux, use the Remmina utility to connect via RDP.

Download and install the Remmina client:

      sudo aptaddrepository ppa:remminappateam/remminanext
   sudo aptget update
   sudo aptget install remmina remminapluginrdp libfreerdppluginsstandard

Launch the Remmina client.
Create a new connection:

   In the application window, select the protocol: RDP.
   Click New connection profile.
   In the window that opens, specify the parameters:

      Name: connection name (for example, VM name).
      Server: the external IP address or the FQDN of the virtual machine.
      Username.
      Password.

Click Save and Connect to connect to the VM. The new connection will be saved in the list.




In macOS, use the Microsoft Remote Desktop program to connect via RDP. Specify the connection parameters manually or using the RDP configuration file.

To get the RDP configuration file:

Go to management console VK Cloud.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Select the VM you need and go to the Windows tab at the bottom of the page.
Click Download RDP config.

Connect to the VM:

Install and run Microsoft Remote Desktop.
Create a new connection.

   Manual:

      In the application window, click Add PC.
      Specify the parameters of the new connection:
         PC name: the external IP address or the FQDN of the virtual machine.
         User account: select Add User Account and specify the credentials:
            Username.
            Password.
      Click Add — the new connection will appear in the list.

   Using the configuration file:

      In the application window, in the upper dropdown menu, select Import from RDP file.
      Select the configuration file and click Import.

Find a new connection in the list and doubleclick on it to connect to the VM.




To connect via RDP, specify the connection parameters manually or using the RDP configuration file.


How to get the RDP configuration file for VK Cloud VM

Go to management console VK Cloud.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Click on the name of the VM you need to go to the VM page.
Go to the General information tab and select the Windows tab at the bottom of the page.
Click Download RDP config.



Connect to the VM:

Open Microsoft Remote Desktop Connection.
Set up the connection.

   Manual:

      In the Computer field, enter the IP address or FQDN of the virtual machine.
      Click Connect.
      In the window that opens, enter the credentials:

         Username.
         Password.

      Click OK.

   Using the configuration file:

      Click Show Options → General.
      In the block Connection settings click Open.
      Select the configuration file and click Open.
      Press the button Connect and confirm the connection again in the window that opens.
      In the operating system authorization window, enter ``.






At the first connection, confirm the use of the certificate.
description: How to connect to a Windows VM via RDP.

title: Managing VM
data:
You can change the parameters and status of a virtual machine on the VK Cloud platform in management console or using the OpenStack command line interface.

Getting a virtual machine ID

To manage a VM using the OpenStack CLI, you need a vm ID.




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
In the list of VMs, click on the name of the VM whose ID you want to find out.
On the VM page, go to the General information tab.
Find the row ID of the virtual machine in the table.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Do one of the following.

   If you know the VM name, get information about the VM and find the string with the id:

            openstack server show

   If the exact name of the VM is unknown, output a list of virtual machines and find the necessary one in it:

            openstack server list


heading(Starting, stopping, reboot the VM)idstart_stop_restart_vm




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Change the VM state in one of the ways.

    Using group operations — for multiple VMs:

        In the list of virtual machines, select the VMs whose state you want to change.
        Above the list of VMs, click the button with the required action.
        Confirm the action.

    Through the context menu — for one VM:

        Click   for the VM whose state you want to change.
        Select and confirm the action.

    On the virtual machine page:

        In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose state you want to change.
        On the VM page, go to the General information tab.
        To the right above the table with VM parameters, click on the icon of the required action.
        Confirm the action.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Run the appropriate command.

   Start VM:

            openstack server start

   Stop VM:

            openstack server stop

   Restart VM:

            openstack server reboot


Forced VM reboot

If the VM is not responding, use a forced reboot.



The forced restart of the VM corresponds to the power off and on (power cycling).The reboot assumes the correct shutdown of the VM operating system (graceful shutdown).






Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Force a VM restart in one of the ways.

    Through the context menu:

        Click   for the required VM.
        Select Force reboot and confirm the action.

    On the virtual machine page:

        In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose state you want to change.
        On the VM page, go to the General information tab.
        Above the table with VM parameters, click More.
        Click Force reboot and confirm the action.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Force a VM reboot:

      openstack server reboot hard


VM block and unblock

Block the VM if you need to prohibit changing its state and parameters.

A blocked virtual machine cannot be started or stopped, nor can it be restarted. It is not possible to replace disks and change the network interface settings of a blocked VM.




Management console




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Block or unblock the VM in one of the ways.

    Through the context menu:

        Click   for the required VM.
        Select and confirm the action.

    On the virtual machine page:

        In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose state you want to change.
        On the VM page, go to the General information tab.
        Above the table with VM parameters, click More.
        Select and confirm the action.

heading(Deleting a VM)iddelete_vm

On the VK Cloud platform, the virtual machine is deleted by default along with the main disk (root disk). Deleting additional disks depends on the settings of the corresponding policy.



The deletion operation is irreversible! Save the necessary data before deleting the VM.



Prepare the VM for deletion.

   If you need to save the main disk, clone it or replace it with an unnecessary one.

   Disconnect from the VM additional disks that need to be saved.

      Additional disks for which the delete_on_termination: False property is set in the deletion policy can not be disconnected from the VM.

      Check the disk deletion policy — OpenStack CLI

      Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

      Run the command:

                  openstack server show  oscomputeapiversion 2.42

         Find the string volumes_attached. It lists the disk IDs and specifies their deletion policy — property delete_on_termination (True or False).


After saving the necessary data, delete the VM.

   Management console
   OpenStack CLI


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
   Delete the VM in one of the ways.

      Using group operations — for multiple VMs:

         In the list of virtual machines, select the VMs that you want to delete.
         In the menu above the VM list, click Delete.
         Confirm the action.

      Through the context menu — for one VM:

         Click   for the VM that you want to delete.
         Select Delete and confirm the action.

      On the virtual machine page:

         In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM that you want to delete.
         On the VM page, go to the General information tab.
         To the right above the table with VM parameters, click on the trash icon.
         Confirm the action.


   Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.
   Delete the VM:

            openstack server delete


Renaming and changing the VM type

On the VK Cloud platform, you can rename a virtual machine, as well as change the type of VM — the number of processors (vCPU) and the amount of RAM.



If the VM type changes, the VM will be rebooted.






Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Change the VM name or type in one of the ways.

   Through the context menu:

      Click   for the required VM.
      Select an action.
      Fill in the input field and click Save.

   On the virtual machine page:

      In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose state you want to change.
      On the VM page, go to the General information tab.
      Above the table with VM parameters, click More.
      Select an action.
      Fill in the input field and click Save.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Perform the required action.

   Rename VM:

            openstack server set name

   Change VM type:

      Get a list of available configuration templates and copy the template ID:

                  openstack flavor list all

      Start changing the VM type and wait for the process to finish:

                  openstack server resize flavor


Assigning tags

Tags allow you to filter the list of virtual machines and find the right VM faster. Use existing tags or create your own tag and choose a color for it.




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Click   for the required VM.
Check the tags or click Create a new tag.
To add a new tag, enter its name, select a color, and click Add tag.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Run the appropriate command.

   Output a list of VM tags:

            nova servertaglist

   Assign a VM tag:

            nova servertagadd

   Delete a tag from a VM:

            nova servertagdelete

   Delete all tags from a VM:

            nova servertagdeleteall


heading(Setting and changing a password)idpassword

In VK Cloud images (except Bitrix), the root account is blocked for security purposes and an account has been added for use by default.

You can see the default account name in the list below or in the password setup window.


List of default accounts for different OS

 Operating system  Username 
    
 AlmaLinux  almalinux 
 ALT Linux  altlinux 
 Astra Linux  astra 
 Bitrix  root 
 CentOS  centos 
 Debian  debian 
 Fedora  fedora 
 FreeBSD  freebsd 
 openSUSE  opensuse 
 Ubuntu  ubuntu 
 RED OS  redos 
 Windows  Admin 



You need to set the default account password by yourself during your first authorization in the OS. The set password can be changed.

Conditions for setting a password:

the virtual machine is running and the OS boot process has finished;
the QEMU guest agent is installed and running (state — running).



In virtual machines created from the VK Cloud image, the QEMU guest agent is available by default.



Command to check the status of the QEMU guest agent:




Windows
Linux




sc query qemuga





systemctl status qemuguestagent








Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Set the password in one of the ways.

    Through the context menu:

        Click   for the required VM.
        Select Set password.
        Enter a new password or click Generate.
        Click Set password.

    On the virtual machine page:

        In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose state you want to change.
        On the VM page, go to the General information tab or to the Console.
        Above the table with VM parameters or above the console window, click Set password.
        Enter a new password or click Generate.
        Click Set password.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Set a password:

      openstack server set rootpassword


The password must be at least 8 characters long and contain letters of the Latin alphabet, numbers, and characters !, ", #, $, %, &, (, ), *, +, ,, , ., :, ;, `, ?, @, , , ^, _,   `, , , ~`.

Password recovery

Password recovery generated for the default user is available only for Windows virtual machines created on a private network. To get a password, you need the private key of the key pair selected when creating the VM.



If the password was changed after the VM was created or the VM was created on the extnet network, set a new password.






Management console




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Open the password receipt window using one of the following methods.

    Through the context menu:

        Click   for the required VM.
        Select Get password.

    On the virtual machine page:

        In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose state you want to change.
        On the VM page, go to the General information tab.
        Above the table with VM parameters, click More.
        Choose Get password.

In the window that opens, click Private key file or paste the contents of the key into the Private key field.
Click Decrypt password.
A field will appear in the window Password. Copy the password by clicking the icon in the field.

Restoring VM access by key

To restore access to a Linux virtual machine via SSH using a key pair, you need to know the password of the OS user.

Get a public key.

   If the public key file is lost, go to the directory with the private key file and run the command:

            sshkeygen y f  >

   If the private key file is lost, create a new key pair.

Create a link to the file with the public key.

   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Go to Object storage → Buckets.
   Use an existing package or create a new one.
   Add file with a public key in the bucket.
   Enable access by the link to this file.
   Copy the link to the file with the public key.

Upload the public key to the VM.

   Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
   In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM you need.
   On the VM page, go to the tab Console.
   Use the default username and password to sign in to the VM OS.
   Download the file with the public key:

            wget

   Copy the public key to the file authorized_keys:

            cat  >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys

Check the possibility of key access.

   Go to the terminal of the computer where the private key is stored.
   Connect to the VM via SSH:

            ssh i  @

Viewing the event log

The event log contains information about changes in the VM state and user actions.




OpenStack CLI




Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Run the appropriate command.

   View the event log (extended format):

            openstack server event list long

   View the event log (short format):

            openstack server event list

   Use the event ID from the Request ID column to display detailed information about the event:

            openstack server event show

Examples of events:

start / stop — starting / stopping a VM;
resize / confirmResize — starting VM type change / confirmation;
extend_volume — increasing the disk size;
create — creating a VM;
livemigration — VM migration.
description: How to manage VM, its settings and resources.

title: Connecting network to VM
data:
A virtual machine can be connected to the network using a port. Port — VM virtual network card for which entities are configured:

security groups;
connected network;
DNS name.

Learn more about networks and ports in the sections Managing networks and subnets and Managing ports.

Connecting the network to the VM



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to management console VK Cloud.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Select the required VM and go to the Networks tab.
Click Add connection.
In the window that appears:

   Name: set the network name.
   Network for connect: select a value from the list:

      Create new network: more about networks and ports in the sections Managing networks and subnets.
      External network (extnet): the virtual machine will be automatically assigned an IP address.
      Existing network.

      When selecting an existing network, set the following parameters:

      Assign external IP: enable it if you need access to the VM via the Internet.
      DNSname: the name by which you can access the VM via private DNS.
      Set IPaddress: enable to set a specific IP address from the subnet address pool.

   Firewall settings: specify the necessary security groups. For more information, see Managing firewall rules.

Click Save.




Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Connecting to an existing port

Get the ID of the virtual machine that you plan to connect to the network:

      openstack server list

Get a list of networks and their subnets:

      openstack network list

Get a list of available ports on the required network:

      openstack port list network

Attach the selected port to the VM:

      openstack server add port

Make sure that the port is successfully connected to the VM:

      openstack port list server

Creating a new port

Get a list of networks and their subnets:

      openstack network list

Get a list of IP addresses for the subnet you plan to connect to:

      openstack subnet list network

Get a list of security groups:

      openstack security group list

Create a port using one of the following methods:

   In the right network and with the default security group:

            openstack port create  network

   With parameters specified:

            openstack port create  \
                            network  \
                            fixedip subnet,ipaddress \
                            securitygroup

      To view the full list of supported parameters, run the command:

            openstack port create help

      It is also possible to create a port with DHCP options.

      If necessary, set a floating IP address to the port.

   As a result, the ID of the created port and other information about it will be displayed.

Get the ID of the virtual machine that you plan to connect to the network:

      openstack server list

Attach the created port to the VM:

      openstack server add port

Make sure that the port is successfully connected to the VM:

      openstack port list server


Deleting a VM network



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to management console VK Cloud.
Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
Select the required VM and go to the Networks tab.
Do one of the following for the required network:

   Select the network using the checkbox, then click the Delete button.
   Click   for the connected network and select Delete connection.

In the window that appears, click Confirm.

The network connection to the VM will be deleted, but the previously created port will remain in the status Not connected. For more information about removing ports, see Managing ports.




Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.
Get the VM ID:

      openstack server list

Get a list of ports from the VM:

      openstack port list server

Delete the unnecessary port:

      openstack port delete
description: How to create a port and connect a network to a VM.

title: VM diagnostics
data:
In emergency situations and when there is no connection to the VM over the network, use VNC console or view VM message logs.



Information about the user's actions with the VM and about changes in its state is contained in the event log OpenStack.

The VNC console

VNC Console is a virtual machine diagnostics and management tool that runs in the browser. Use the VNC console if:

the virtual machine does not have an external IP address or is not connected to the Internet;
recommended VM connection methods (via SSH or RDP) don't work.

Access to the VNC console appears immediately after the virtual machine is started. This allows you to detect failures during the boot of the operating system.

Features of working with the VNC console:

you can only use the Latin alphabet to enter text;
the clipboard in the VNC console is not available, you cannot copy and paste the text.

To connect VM via VNC console:

Open the console:

    Management console
    OpenStack CLI


    Go to VK Cloud management console.
    Go to the Cloud Servers → Virtual machines section.
    In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM you need.
    Go to the Console tab.


    Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

    Get a link to the VNC console page.

              openstack console url show

       Example output:

              +++
        Field  Value                                                                                 
       +++
        type   novnc                                                                                
        url    https://infra.mail.ru:6080/vnc_auto.html?token2022498043eb453585c7310a18e27941 
       +++

    Use the link to open the VNC console page in the browser.


       If the link has expired, run the command again to get a new link.


If the virtual machine is not running, click the start button on the tab.
Set a password to log into the OS if you haven't done it already. Write down the account name and password.
(Optional) Click the Open in new window button to open the console in a separate browser window.
Enter the login and password in the console.

VNC console control buttons are available in the VK Cloud management console interface and in a separate window:

Send CtrAltDel** — the action of the button depends on the VM's operating system (reboot, opening the lock window, etc.).
Update Session** — use it to reconnect to the VNC console.

VM message logs

OpenStack provides support for a console running through a VM serial port. This allows you to view the boot logs and other diagnostic information, regardless of the state of the operating system and access to the VM over the network.

If the VM was created from a custom image, configure the console. To do this, add the following parameters to GRUB:

consoletty0 consolettyS0,115200n8



OpenStack CLI




Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Output all log entries:

      openstack console log show

Output a limited number of records:

      openstack console log show lines
description: Remote access to a Windows or Linux VM using a VNC console. VM diagnostics.

title: Searching and filtering VM
data:
Use filtering to quickly find the virtual machines you need:

Go to your VK Cloud management console.

Go to Cloud computing → Virtual machines.

Click the Search by instances box. A list of available filters will open:

    Virtual machine types — select the type: virtual machines, Kubernetes instances, or ML Platform.
    Statuses — select the Instance running option to leave only active instances in the list.
    Backups — use the option to check whether VMs are included in the automatic backup plan:

        Yes — only VMs included in automatic backup plans will remain in the list.
        None — only VMs that are not included in any automatic backup plan will remain in the list.

        Manually creating VM backups does not affect filtering.


    Tags — select the required tags. Only VMs that have all the selected tags will remain in the list.
    Filter by VM name — start filling in the search field. Only VMs which names begin with the entered characters will remain in the list.

Different filters can be combined for a more accurate VM search.
description: How to find a VM you need by name or settings.

title: Disks
data:
The data storage system on the VK Cloud platform is organized using network drives. The configuration of the main disk is set at the stage of creating a virtual machine, additional disks can be created, later connect to the necessary VMs. For created disks, the resizing and changing disk type operations are available. Disks can be shared between projects and virtual machines, disconnect from VM, make bootable and not bootable. Disks that are no longer in use can be deleted.

Creating a disk

Creating HDD and SSD drives is available by default in all configurations. To create LL NVME discs contact technical support and request access to highperformance configurations and disks. Learn more about disk types — to the article Cloud Servers overview.



Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.

   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM for which you want to create a disk.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Above the list of disks, click Create disk.
Specify the disk parameters:

   Disk Name: required field. If necessary, click Add description and enter the text in the field that appears.
   Source: select the appropriate option for the parameter:

      Empty disk: fill in the parameters Disk Type and Availability zone.
      Disk snapshot: in the List of snapshots field, select the snapshot from which you want to create a disk.
      Disk image: fill in the parameters Disk Type, Availability zone and Disk image.
      Disk: in the Cloning disk field, select the required disk.

   Size: specify the disk size in gigabytes.
   Boot disk: enable the option if you need to make the disk bootable.


      The boot disk can be used as the VM's main (root) disk or connected to the VM as an additional disk from which the operating system can be booted.


   Connect disk to instance: if you need to connect a disk to a VM immediately after creation, enable this option and select the VM you need in the field Choose instance.

Click the Create disk button.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Select in the table the type of disk, determine its name in the API and the availability zone suitable for placement.

View the available disk types and copy the type ID corresponding to the name in the API.

      openstack volume type list

View the availability zones and copy the name of the selected zone:

      openstack availability zone list volume

Create a disk of a certain type and size in the selected availability zone:

      openstack volume create type  size  availabilityzone

   Additional command parameters:

   image  — ID of the image from which the disk will be created;
   snapshot  — ID of the snapshot from which the disk will be created;
   description  — custom disk description;
   property  — custom disk properties;
   bootable — create a boot disk.

Increasing the disk size with rebooting

Restrictions related to changing the VM disk size on the VK Cloud platform:

The disk size cannot be reduced.
If disks with the High IOPS SSD and Low Latency NVME type have snapshots, you cannot increase the size of these disks.




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.

   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose disk size you want to increase.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Use one of the methods to open the disk resizing window.

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select Change disk size.

   On the disk page:

      Click on the name of the disk whose size you want to change.
      On the disk page, go to the tab General information.
      Above the table with the disk parameters, click the Change disk size button.

In the window that opens, specify Disk size.
Click the button Save.
Reboot the VM.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Output a list of disks:

      openstack volume list

Check the disk status in the Status column. Successful expansion is guaranteed only for disks with the status available or inuse.

Copy the disk ID.

Increase the disk by specifying the new size in gigabytes.

   If the disk is disconnected from the VM (Status: available):

               openstack volume set size

   If the disk is connected to the VM (Status: inuse):

               cinder extend

Reboot the VM.

Increasing the disk size without rebooting

Increase the virtual disk size in your VK Cloud management console or via Openstack CLI, but do not reboot the VM. This will change the disk size, but will not change the size of the disk partitions in the OS.
Increase the size of disk partitions in the VM operating system:

   Windows
   Linux


   Connect to the VM via RDP or via console.
   Open Disk Management with administrator permissions (diskmgmt.msc).
   Choose Extend Volume in rightclick menu of the volume that you want to extend.
   Increase the disk size.


   Connect to the VM via SSH or via console.
   Find out what disk partitions are on the VM and what file systems they have. To do this, run the command:

              df Th

      In the response, find the partition you want to resize and look at its file system in the Type column. Typically, you need to resize /dev/vda1.
   Increase the partition size.

      The example command:

              growpart /dev/vda 1 # you need a space before 1

   Increase the file system size to the size of the partition. Depending on the directory file system, use the command:

      Ext1, Ext2, Ext3, Ext4
      XFS


              sudo resize2fs /dev/vda1 # you need no space before 1

              sudo xfs_growfs d /dev/vda1

   Use the df Th command to verify that the partition size has changed.


Cloning disk



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.
   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose disk size you want to increase.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Use one of the methods to open the disk cloning window.

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select Clone disk.

   On the disk page:

      Click on the name of the disk whose size you want to change.
      On the disk page, go to the tab General information.
      Above the table with the disk parameters, click the More and choose Clone disk option.

On the page that opens, specify the parameters of the new disk.
Click the Create disk button.




Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.
Define:

   the required type of disk;
   its name in the API;
   an accessibility zone suitable for accommodation.

View the available disk types and copy the type ID corresponding to the name in the API.

      openstack volume type list

View the availability zones and copy the name of the required zone:

      openstack availability zone list volume

Clone a disk based on an existing one:

      openstack volume create type  size  availabilityzone  source


Changing the disk type

Creating HDD and SSD drives is available by default in all configurations. To use LL NVME discs contact technical support and request access to highperformance configurations and disks. Learn more about disk types — to the article Cloud Servers overview.




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.

   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose disk type you want to change.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Use one of the methods to open the disk type change window.

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select Change disk type.

   On the disk page:

      Click on the name of the disk whose type you want to change.
      On the disk page, go to the General Information tab.
      Above the table with the disk parameters, click Change disk type.


   If the Change disk type option is not active, disconnect the disk from the VM.


In the window that opens, select Disk Type and click Confirm.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Select in the table a new disk type and define its name in the API.

View the list of available disk types and copy the type ID corresponding to the name in the API.

      openstack volume type list

View the list of disks and copy the ID of the disk whose type you want to change:

      openstack volume list long

Change the disk type:

      openstack volume set type  retypepolicy ondemand


Changing the bootable attribute

Make the disk bootable to use it as the VM's primary (root) disk. The boot disk can also be used as an additional VM disk to boot the operating system.

To exclude the possibility of accidental booting from the disk, make it nonbootable.




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.

   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the VM name.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Change the “bootable” attribute in one of the ways.

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select Make bootable (Make it nonbootable).

   On the disk page:

      Click on the disk name.
      On the disk page, go to the General Information tab.
      Above the table with the disk parameters, click More and select Make bootable (Make it nonbootable).

In the window that opens, click Confirm.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Run the appropriate command.

   Make a disk bootable:

            openstack volume set bootable

   Make the disk nonbootable:

            openstack volume set nonbootable

Check the result:

      openstack volume show


Connecting a disk to a VM




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Disks.
Find a disk in the list that is not connected to the VM: the icon to the left of the disk name is blue, when you hover over it, the inscription appears Не подключен к инстансу.
Use one of the methods to open the virtual machine selection window to attach the disk.

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select Connect to instance.

   On the disk page:

      Click on the name of the disk that you want to connect to the VM.
      On the disk page, go to the General Information tab.
      Above the list of disks, click More and select Connect to instance.

In the window that opens, specify the virtual machine in the field Choose instance.
Click the Connect disk.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Output a list of disks and copy the disk ID:

      openstack volume list

Print the list of virtual machines and copy the ID of the virtual machine to which you want to connect the disk:

      openstack server list

Connect the disk:

      openstack server add volume

View the disk information to check the result (the attachments field):

      openstack volume show


Disconnecting a disk from a VM



To disable the VM's main (root) disk, use the option Replacing the root disk.






Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.

   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM from which you want to disconnect the disk.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Disconnect the disk from the VM in one of the ways.

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select Disconnect from instance.

   On the disk page:

      Click on the name of the disk that you want to disconnect from the VM.
      On the disk page, go to the General Information tab.
      Above the list of disks, click More and select Disconnect from instance.

In the window that opens, check the name of the disk and click Confirm.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Output a list of disks and copy the disk ID:

      openstack volume list

Output a list of virtual machines and copy the ID of the virtual machine from which you want to disconnect the disk:

      openstack server list

Disconnect the disk:

      openstack server remove volume

View the disk information to check the result (the attachments field):

      openstack volume show


Replacing the root disk

Before replacing the main disk stop the VM.




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Disconnect from VM the disk that will be used to replace the main one.
Clone the target disk if necessary.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.

   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose main disk you want to replace.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Use one of the methods to open the disk replacement window.

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select Replace root disk.

   On the disk page:

      Click on the name of the disk you want to replace.
      On the disk page, go to the General Information tab.
      Above the list of disks, click More and select Replace root disk.

In the window that opens, select New root disk and click Replace.


   If the required disk is not in the list, check that it is disconnected from the VM.


Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Get access token.
View the list of virtual machines and copy the ID of the virtual machine whose main disk needs to be replaced:

      openstack server list

View the list of disks:

      openstack volume list long

Check the parameters of the disk that is selected to replace the main one:

   The disk is disconnected from the VM (Status: available). If not, disconnect the disk.
   The disk is bootable (Bootable: true). If not, make it bootable.

Copy the ID of the selected disk.
Run the command to replace the main disk:

   curl g i X POST https://infra.mail.ru:8774/v2.1/servers//action \
   H "Accept: application/json" \
   H "ContentType: application/json" \
   H "UserAgent: pythoncinderclient" \
   H "XAuthToken: " \
   d '"replaceRoot": "volume_id": ""'


Transfer disks between projects




OpenStack CLI




Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to it (to both projects).

Sign in to the project you want to move the disk from.
Disconnect from VM the disk to be moved.
View the list of disks:

      openstack volume list long

Make sure that the disk is disconnected from the VM (Status: available).
Copy the disk ID.
Create a request to move the disk:

      openstack volume transfer request create

Copy the auth_key and id values.
Review the list of disks and make sure that the status of the disk being moved has changed to awaitingtransfer:

      openstack volume list

Sign in to the project you want to move the disk to.
Move the disk:

            openstack volume transfer request accept authkey

Make sure that the disk appears in the project:

            openstack volume show

Additional commands for working with disk transfer requests

View the list of transfer requests:

      openstack volume transfer request list

Delete a transfer request:

      openstack volume transfer request delete


Deleting a disk

Before deleting disconnect the disk from the VM.



When you delete a disk, all its snapshots will be deleted.






Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.

   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM whose disk you want to delete.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Delete the disk in one of the ways.

   Using group operations — for multiple disks:

      Select the disks you want to delete with the checkboxes.
      Above the list of disks, click the Delete disk button.

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select Delete disk.

   On the disk page:

      Click on the name of the disk you want to delete.
      On the disk page, go to the General Information tab.
      To the right above the table with the disk parameters, click on the trash icon.

In the window that opens, check the disk name and click Confirm.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Output a list of disks using the openstack volume list command and check its status: if the disk is connected to the VM (Status: inuse), disconnect it.

Copy the disk ID.

Delete the disk.

         openstack volume delete


Disk snapshots

A disk snapshot is a file that stores a copy of a disk taken at a certain point in time. The snapshot can be used to create a new VM or a new disk.

Creating a snapshot




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.

   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the name of the VM that you plan to create a disk snapshot for.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Use one of the methods to open the disk snapshot creation window.

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select Create snapshot.

   On the disk page:

      Click on the name of the disk for which you want to create a snapshot.
      On the disk page, go to the Snapshots tab.
      Above the list of snapshots, click Create snapshot.

In the window that opens, specify the parameters:

   Name snapshot.
   Source disk.

Click Create snapshot.





Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Output a list of disks:

      openstack volume list

Copy the ID of the required disk.

Create a disk snapshot.

   If the disk is disconnected from the VM (Status: available):

               openstack volume snapshot create volume

   If the disk is connected to the VM (Status: inuse):

               openstack volume snapshot create force volume


Using snapshots




Management console
OpenStack CLI




Go to VK Cloud management console.
Open the page with the required list of disks.

   All disks: go to Cloud Servers → Disks.

   Disks of a specific virtual machine:

      Go to Cloud Servers → Virtual machines.
      In the list of virtual machines, click on the VM name.
      On the VM page, go to the Disks tab.

Open the page with the list of snapshots using one of the following methods:

   Via the disk context menu:

      Click   for the disk.
      Select List of snapshots.

   On the disk page:

      Click on the name of the disk whose snapshots you want to view.
      On the disk page, go to the Snapshots tab or on the General Information tab, click the More button and select List of snapshots.

Click   for the snapshot and select the required option:

   Create VM instance — to go to the virtual machine creation page.
   Create disk — to go to the disk creation page.
   Delete disk snapshot — to delete a snapshot.


      To delete multiple snapshots, select the snapshots with the checkboxes and click the Delete snapshot button.


Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Run the appropriate command.

   Display a list of disk snapshots:

            openstack volume snapshot list volume
   Display a list of disk snapshots of the entire project:

            openstack volume snapshot list project

   Change snapshot properties:

            openstack volume snapshot set

      Available properties:

     name — snapshot name;
     description — snapshot description;
     property — data in the keyvalue format;
     noproperty — remove additional values.

   Delete a disk snapshot:

            openstack volume snapshot delete

title: Images management
data:
An image is a file that contains a virtual disk with an installed operating system or other data. Images are used to create virtual machines in the cloud.

Creating an image

The VK Cloud service allows you to create an image from the disk of an existing virtual machine.



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Images.
Click the Create button.
In the window that appears:

   Source: choose Disk.
   Select disk: select the disk of the existing VM. The VM must be stopped.
   Name of the image: specify the name of the image.
   Click the Create image button.






The disk to create the image must be disconnected from the VM and have the status available.



Get the ID of the disk:

      openstack volume list

Create an image:

      openstack image create volume

Check the image creation:

      openstack image list name

   The successfully created image must have the status active.

Importing an image

The VK Cloud service supports uploading your own virtual machine images with some restrictions by operating systems.



Only RAW images are supported. If your image is in a different format, convert it.





The recommended way to import an image is using the CLI.

When downloading through your VK Cloud management console, the size of the downloaded file is limited.





Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Images.
Click the Create button.
In the window that appears:

   Source: select File.
   Selected file: upload the image file in RAW format.
   Name of the image: specify the name of the image.
   Click the Create image button.




The parameters of the image import command depend on the need for backup support:

If support is not needed, run the command:

      openstack image create private containerformat bare diskformat raw property stores3 file

If support is needed, add parameters property hw_qemu_guest_agentyes property os_require_quiesceyes to the command above.

Exporting an image



OpenStack CLI
cURL



Get the ID of the image from the list:

      openstack image list

Export the image:

      openstack image save file .raw


Get the access token XAuthToken.
Run the command:

      curl H "XAuthToken:token" "https://infra.mail.ru:9292/v2/images/image ID/file" output .raw


Changing the visibility status of an image

Changing the visibility status of an image allows you to access an image from multiple projects. Sharing an image across multiple projects allows you to speed up the deployment of virtual machines.

The VK Cloud service provides the following image visibility statuses for users:

 Status       Description                                         

 private    The image is for personal access only               
 shared     The image can be used in several projects           



Management console
OpenStack CLI





Through your VK Cloud management console, you can allow access to the image only for certain projects.



To change the visibility status of an image:

Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Images.
Click   for the required image and select Share image.
In the window that appears:

   Choose one of the options:

      My projects: select the required projects from the dropdown list.
      Other projects: specify the project ID.

   Click the Allow access button.




To change the visibility status of an image:

Get the ID of the image from the list:

      openstack image list

Display detailed information about the individual image:

      openstack image show

   The visibility status of the image is displayed in the visibility line.

Change the image status:

      openstack image set 

To share an image in the status shared:

Add an image to the project:

      openstack image add project

Confirm adding the image to the project:

      openstack image set accept

To view the projects that have access to the image, run the command:

openstack image member list

Deleting an image



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud Servers → Images.
Do one of the following for the required image:

   Select the image using the checkbox, then click Delete.
   Click   for the required image and select Remove image.

Click the Confirm button.




To delete an image that is not attached to projects:

openstack image delete

To delete an image from a project:

openstack image remove project

title: Images meta tags
data:
The image may have meta tags that affect the configuration of the virtual machine and the guest operating system. Meta tags are set when editing the image.

Supported image meta tags

VM image tags are divided into:

os_*: guest operating system (OS) settings;
hw_*: virtual machine settings;
mcs_*: VM properties used for sorting in VK Cloud management console;
other tags that affect the work with the image.

 Name  Description  Default value 
      
 os_type  The type of guest OS created from the image inside the VM. Affects the VM configuration. For example, special hypervisor features will be enabled for Windows to improve the stability and performance of the guest OS  Depends on the OS 
 mcs_os_type  The type of guest OS inside the VM. Used for sorting in the management console  
 os_distro  The distribution of the guest OS created from the image inside the virtual machine. Affects VM configuration, for example, types of virtual network devices  
 mcs_os_distro  The distribution of the guest OS inside the VM. Used for sorting in the management console  
 os_version  Version of the guest OS inside the VM  
 mcs_os_version  The version of the guest OS inside the VM. Used for sorting in the management console  
 os_admin_user  The user is inside the guest OS with administrator rights; the password can be set via management console  
 os_require_quiesce  The flag responsible for freezing the file system before taking snapshots of attached disks. If yes, then if the file system freezes unsuccessfully, the snapshot creation operation will be canceled  no 
 hw_qemu_guest_agent  A sign of the presence of a QEMU agent inside the guest OS. If True, it makes available the possibility of changing the user's password and freezing the file system for backup  False 
 mcs_name  The name of the image that is displayed to the user of the management console

Installing a meta tag



OpenStack CLI

          systeminfo

  Create the image.
  Set meta tags:

          openstack image set property

     Example:

          openstack image set property os_type"windows" property os_distro"win2k16" property os_require_quiesce"yes" property hw_vif_model"virtio" 7c81ffd7199d442887678120fa1b3aae
