title: Standard routers
data:
You can manage routers: view, edit and delete them.

Viewing a list of routers and information about them



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project.
Go to Virtual networks → Routers.

   A list of routers will be displayed.

Click on the name of the necessary router.

   A page with detailed information about the router will open. You can also edit router parameters on this page.




Make sure that:

   OpenStack CLI is installed.
   You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.

To see a list of routers and their IDs, run the command:

      openstack router list

To see detailed information about a router, run the command:

      openstack router show

   In the output of the command:

   id: the router's ID.
   external_gateway_info: information on connection to external network. A blank field means that connection to the external network is not configured.
   interfaces_info: information about interfaces of the router. A blank field means that no interfaces have been added.
   routes: information about static router routes. An empty field means no static routes were added.

Adding a router



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project.
Go to Virtual networks → Routers.
Click the Add router button.
Set the router parameters:

   Name.
   External network connection: if this option is selected, the router will have Internet access and a public IP address.

     Select this option if you plan to assign floating IP addresses to ports on subnets connected to the router and provide Internet access from these subnets.

   Subnet List: one or more subnets to be connected to the router.

Click the Create button.




Make sure that:

    OpenStack CLI is installed.
    You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.

Create a router of the necessary type:

   With connection to external network
   Without connection to the external network


      openstack router create  externalgateway extnet


      openstack router create


   A router with an external network connection will have Internet access and a public IP address. Create this type of router if you plan to assign floating IP addresses to ports on subnets connected to the router and provide Internet access from those subnets.

Learn how to connect one or more interfaces to the router by either editing the router or managing its interfaces directly.

Editing a router



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project.
Go to Virtual networks → Routers.
Perform one of the actions for the router you want to edit:

   Click the name of the router and then in the General information tab, click Edit router.
   Click   for the router and select Edit router.

Perform one of the available actions:

   Change the router name.
   Manage the connection to the external network: you can enable or disable the corresponding option. If this option is selected, the router will have Internet access and a public IP address.

     Select this option if you plan to assign floating IP addresses to ports on subnets connected to the router and provide Internet access from those subnets.

   Manage the subnets connected to the router. You can add new subnets to the router by selecting them from the list, or remove already added subnets.


     You can also add or remove subnets by changing the router interface.


After editing the router, click the Save button.




Make sure that:

    OpenStack CLI is installed.
    You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.
Get the ID of the necessary router.
Perform one of the available actions:

   Change the name of the router:

          openstack router set  name

   Manage the connection to the external network:

     Enable external network connection
     Disable external network connection


          openstack router set  externalgateway extnet


          openstack router unset  externalgateway


     Connect the router to an external network if you plan to assign floating IP addresses to ports on subnets connected to the router and provide Internet access from those subnets.

   Manage the subnets connected to the router. You can add new subnets to the router, or remove already added subnets.

     Add a subnet
     Remove a subnet


     Get the ID of the necessary subnet.
     Run the command:

                openstack router add subnet

     As a result:

     The selected subnet will be connected to the router.
     Interfaces INTERFACE_DISTRIBUTED and (if the router is connected to an external network) SNAT related to this subnet will appear in the list of interfaces.


          openstack router remove subnet

     As a result:

     The following will be deleted:
       The port corresponding to the interface of the subnet being removed.
       The SNAT interface (if there is one) and its corresponding port.

     The subnet, where those interfaces were located, will be removed from the router.


     You can also add or remove a subnet by changing the interface of the router.


Managing an interface

Router interface management is an alternative to managing subnets connected to it.



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to the router page and select tab Interfaces.

To add an interface:

    Click the Add Interface button.
    Select the required subnet from the list.
    Click the Add Interface button.

    As a result:

    The selected subnet will be connected to the router.
    The INTERFACE_DISTRIBUTED and (if Connect to external network is selected) SNAT interfaces related to this subnet will appear in the list of interfaces.

To remove an interface:

    Click   for the interface and select Remove Interface.
    Confirm the deletion.

    As a result:

    The corresponding SNAT interface (if present) will also be removed.
    The subnet that this interface was on will be disconnected from the router.




Make sure that:

    OpenStack CLI is installed.
    You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.

Get the ID of the necessary router.

To add an interface:

    Get the ID of the OpenStack port located on the subnet you want to connect to the router. This port should not be used by any objects (load balancers, virtual machines, etc.) If there is no such port, create it.
    Run the command:

              openstack router add port

    As a result:

    The selected subnet will be connected to the router.
    The INTERFACE_DISTRIBUTED and (if the router is connected to an external network) SNAT interfaces related to this subnet will appear in the list of interfaces.


   To get a list of interfaces, see router details using the OpenStack CLI.


To remove an interface:

    Look at the interfaces (ports) configured on the router.
    Run the command:

              openstack router remove port

    As a result:

    Will also be removed:
      port corresponding to the interface to be removed.
      SNAT interface (if any) and its corresponding port.

    The subnet that these interfaces were on will be disconnected from the router.

Managing Static Routes



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to the router page, then select the Static Routes tab.

To add a static route:

    Click the Add Static Route or Add button.
    Set the destination network and specify the network prefix.
    Specify an intermediate node (next hop).
    Click the Add Interface button.

To delete a static route, click   for the required route and select Delete Interface.




Make sure that:

    OpenStack CLI is installed.
    You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.

Get the ID of the necessary router.

To add a static route, run the command:

        openstack router set  route destination,gateway

To remove a static route:

    Look up the static routes configured on the router.
    Run the command:

              openstack router unset  route destination,gateway

To remove all static routes, run the command:

        openstack router set  noroute


Removing the Router



Before deleting the router, delete the static routes and the configured interfaces (if any) one by one before deleting the router.





Management console
OpenStack CLI



This is a group operation: if necessary, you can delete several routers at once by selecting them using the checkboxes.

To remove a router:

Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the required balancer is located.
Go to Virtual networks → Routers.
Do one of the following for the required router:

    Select the router using the checkbox, then click the Remove Router button.
    Click   for the router and select Remove Router.
    Click on the name of the router, then on the General Information tab, click on the Delete Router button.

Confirm the removal of the router.




Make sure that:

    OpenStack CLI is installed.
    You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.

Get the ID of the necessary router.

Run the command:

      openstack router delete
description: Managing standard routers in the virtual networks service.

title: Managing advanced routers
data:
You can manage advanced routers: view, edit and delete them.

Advanced routers are only available with SDN Sprut. To find out which SDN is used in your project or to connect another, contact technical support.

View a list of advanced routers



Management console



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud networks → Routers. A list of routers will be displayed. For advanced routers, the Router Type column indicates Advanced.
Click the name of the router you need. A page will open with detailed information about it. You can edit router parameters on this page .

Adding an advanced router



Management console



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud networks → Routers.
Click the Add router button.
In the Router type field choose Advanced. If this field is missing, SDN Sprut is not enabled in your project. Please, contact technical support, to enable SDN Sprut and advanced routers.
Set parameters of the router:

   Name. You can use numbers, Latin letters, spaces, and special characters: ?, !, ~, @, #, $, %, ^, ", &, _, , +, *, , ;, :, ,, ., /, \, , `  `, , , , , (, ), `.
   Availability zone: choose an availability zone you need.
   Description: an optional field.
   SNAT: enable the option if you need to convert private IP addresses into public ones for access from the project network to the Internet. When you add the router interface directed to an external network, SNAT is enabled automatically.

      SNAT is active only if the router is connected to an external network.


Click the Add button.

Editing an advanced router



Management console



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Go to Cloud networks → Routers.
Open the router editing window by one of the following ways:

   Click the name of the router and then click the Edit button on the General information tab.
   Click   for the router and select Edit router.

You can do the following:

   Edit the name of the router.
   Edit the description of the router.
   Enable or disable SNAT. Enabling the option allows you to convert private IP addresses into public ones for access from the project network to the Internet. When you add the router interface directed to an external network, SNAT is enabled automatically.

      SNAT is active only if the router is connected to an external network.


Click the Save button to complete the editing.

Viewing an advanced router statistics



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Statistics tab.

The tab provides statistical information on the advanced router:

The time when the last information was received from the service. Information about the service status is updated at intervals of up to 5 minutes.
The router's readiness for use.
The number of routes received in announcements from BGP neighbors and added to the routing table.
The number of static routes added to the routing table.
Router interfaces, traffic incoming and outgoing on those interfaces, and overall traffic incoming and outgoing to the router.
Information about BGP sessions: session status, neighbor name, incoming and outgoing BGP announcements, date and time of the last change in the BGP session.
Information about static routes: destination network, intermediate node and status.

Viewing a VPN information

You can find out information about VPN tunnels that use the advanced router.



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the VPN tab.

The tab displays statistical information on the VPN tunnels connected to the advanced router.

To find out the detailed information about a VPN tunnel, click its name. The VPN settings page will open.

Deleting an advanced router

You can delete an advanced router in the same way as a standard router.
description: Adding, editing, deleting advanced routers and viewing statistics.

title: Managing interfaces
data:
To connect the router to subnets, you need to add interfaces. To connect the router to an external network, you need to add an interface directed to the external network.

Adding interfaces of advanced router



Management console





You can also connect a subnet to the router in the Cloud networks → Networks section of your management console.



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Interfaces tab.
Click the Add interface button.
Fill in the Name field. You can use numbers, Latin letters, spaces, and special characters: ?, !, ~, @, #, $, %, ^, ", &, _, , +, *, , ;, :, ,, ., /, \, , `  `, , , , , (, ), `.
Select a subnet from the list or create a new one. If you need the Internet access to the router, select one of the external network subnets:

   internet for SDN Sprut;
   extnet for SDN Neutron.

   An external network is required for SNAT and VPN. You can add only one interface per router with a connection to an external network. When you add an interface with an external network connection, SNAT is enabled automatically, even if the option was not enabled when creating the router.
(Optional) By default, an IP address of the interface is generated automatically. To set a custom IP address, enable the Specify interface IP address option, then enter the address in the field below. You cannot select the first subnet address, for example 10.0.0.1.
(Optional) Add a description for the interface.
Click the Add button.

As a result:

The added interface will appear in the list of interfaces.
The selected subnet will be connected to the router.

Removing interfaces of advanced router



Management console



This is a group operation: you can remove several interfaces at once by selecting them using the checkboxes.

include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Interfaces tab.
Remove the interface in one of the following ways:

    Click   for the interface and select Remove interface.
    Set the checkbox for the required interface, then click the Remove interface button above the table.
Confirm the removal.

As a result:

The interface will be removed.
The interface subnet will be disconnected form the router.
description: Adding and deleting interfaces of advanced router.

title: Static routing
data:
Adding a static route



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Open the Static routes tab.
Click the Add static route button.
Set the destination network and specify the network prefix.
Specify the next hop.
(Optional) Specify a metric that determines the priority of static routes in the routing table.
(Optional) Add a route description.
Click the Add button.

Deleting a static route



Management console



This is a group operation: you can delete several routes at once by selecting them using the checkboxes.

include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Open the Static routes tab.
Delete the route in one of the following ways:

    Click   for the route and select Delete static route.

description: Adding and deleting static routes of advanced router.

title: Dynamic routing
data:
An advanced router allows you to establish connection between autonomous networks using the BGP protocol. To do this, you need to add a BGP router and specify BGP neighbors.

Adding a BGP router


You can only add one BGP router per advanced router.




Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Dynamic Routing tab.
Click the Add a BGP router button.
Specify the name of the BGP router. You can use only numbers, Latin letters, spaces, and special characters: ?, !, ~, @, #, $, %, ^, ", &, _, , +, *, , ;, :, ,, ., /, \, , `  `, , , , , (, ), `.
Specify an IP address for the BGP router — the router interface directed to the transit network. Use the highest IP address on the loopback or physical interface.
Enter an ASN from the range 64512–65534.
(Optional) Disable the BGP router if you do not need to establish a connection at this time. The BGP router will become inactive.
(Optional) Add a description for the BGP router.
Click the Create button.

Editing a BGP router



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Dynamic Routing tab.
Open the editing page of the dynamic router by one of the following ways:

    Click the name of the BGP router, then click the Edit button.
    Click   for the BGP router and select Edit.

You can do the following:

    Edit the router name.
    Edit the router description.
    Enable the ECMP option. The router will create multiple routes to the same destination. When transferring data, if one of the routes is unavailable, another will be automatically selected. This allows for increased throughput and fault tolerance.
    Enable the Graceful restart option. After the peer is restarted, the BGP router will retain its state and continue transmitting data.
    Enable the Long lived graceful restart option. The BGP router will maintain its state for a longer time in the event of a BGP peer failure.
    Disable the BGP router if you do not need to establish communication at the moment. The BGP router will become inactive.
Click the Save changes button.

Deleting a BGP router



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Dynamic Routing tab.
Delete the router in one of the following ways:

    Click   for the router and select Delete.
    Set the checkbox for the required router, then click the Delete button above the table.
Confirm the deletion.

Adding a BGP neighbor

To connect autonomous networks using the BGP protocol, you need to specify the BGP routers which will connect to each other.



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Dynamic Routing tab.
Select the BGP router.
Go to the BGP neighbors tab.
Click Add a BGP neighbor.
(Optional) Specify the name of the BGP neighbor. You can use only numbers, Latin letters, spaces, and special characters: ?, !, ~, @, #, $, %, ^, ", &, _, , +, *, , ;, :, ,, ., /, \, , `  `, , , , , (, ), `.
Specify the interface directed to the transit network of the neighboring BGP router.
Specify the ASN of the remote network. If the network does not have an ASN defined, use private ASNs from the range 64512–65534.
(Optional) Disable the BGP neighbor if you do not need to establish a connection at the moment. The BGP router will not send requests to the remote router.
(Optional) Add a description for the BGP neighbor.
Click the Add button.




After you add the BGP neighbor, the router will try to establish a connection with it. When this is done, you will see:

the mark next to the name of the BGP neighbor is green
BFD is enabled

Editing a BGP neighbor



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Dynamic Routing tab.
Select the BGP router and then go to the BGP neighbors tab.
Select the BGP neighbor.
Open the editing window of the BGP neighbor by one of the following ways:

    Click the BGP neighbor name, then click the Edit button.
    Click   for the BGP neighbor and select Edit.

You can do the following:

    Edit the BGP neighbor name.
    Edit the BGP neighbor description.
    Edit the neighbor operating mode that determines the ability to exchange all routing options for each announcement. You can select the mode in the Add path field:

       off: disable
       on: enable in both directions
       rx: enable reception only
       tx: enable delivery only

    Enable the BFD option. This allows the use of session control via BFD (руBidirectional Forwarding Detection).
    Enable the Next Hop Self option. The BGP neighbor will get the IP adress of the router interface as the next hop.
    Disable the BGP neighbor if the connection is not currently required. The BGP router will not send requests to the remote router.
Click the Save changes button.

Deleting a BGP neighbor



Management console



This is a group operation: you can delete several neighbors at once by setting the checkboxes.

include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Dynamic Routing tab.
Select the BGP router and then go to the BGP neighbors tab.
Select the BGP neighbor.
Delete the BGP neighbor in one of the following ways:

    Click   for the BGP neighbor and select Delete.
    Set the checkbox for the required BGP neighbor, then click the Delete button above the table.
    Click the name of the BGP neighbor, then click the Delete button above the table.
Confirm the deletion.

View a BGP announcement

After setting up a BGP neighbor, an advanced router will begin transmitting to the neighbor BGP announcements of all networks to which its interfaces are directed.

To view BGP announcements:



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Dynamic Routing tab.
Select the BGP router.
Go to the BGP announcements tab.

The tab displays a list of all BGP announcements. Active announcements are marked with green marks.

Adding a BGP announcement



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Dynamic Routing tab.
Select the BGP router and then go to the BGP announcements tab.
Click the Add a BGP announcement button.
Select the type of announcement:

   Static
   Connected


   The announcement conveys information about a manually specified static route.

    Specify the request parameters:

       Network: the IP address with the network mask that will be announced to a BGP neighbor.
       Default Gateway: the gateway IP address. If the gateway is available, the network will be announced in BGP.
       (Optional) Disable the BGP announcement if this network does not need to be announced to a BGP neighbor. The BGP announcement will become inactive.
       (Optional) Add a description for the BGP announcement.
    Click the Add button.


   The announcement conveys information about a subnet connected to the advanced router interface.

   Select a subnet connected to the router in the Connected subnet field.
   Click the Connect button.


Editing a BGP announcement

You can only edit the Static announcements.



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the Dynamic Routing tab.
Select the BGP router and then go to the BGP announcements tab.
Open the editing page of the BGP announcement by one of the following ways:

    Click   for the announcement and select Edit.

title: Setting DNAT rules
data:
To provide access to a private network from the Internet, configure DNAT— destination network address translation for an advanced router. DNAT forwards incoming packets from an external IP address or port to an IP address or port inside the private network. At the same time, from one public IP address, you can configure data transfer to many internal addresses of private networks using unique ports (TCP or UDP).

Adding DNAT rule



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the DNAT tab.
Click plusicon Add a DNAT rule.
Specify a name of the DNAT rule. You can only use numbers, Latin letters, spaces and characters: ?, !, ~, @, #, $, %, ^, ", &, _, , +, *, , ;, :, ,, ., /, \, , `  `, , , , , (, ), `.
Select a router interface that will receive a data packet. If there is no interface you need, select Add a new interface and add a new interface.
Select a data transfer protocol:

   All protocls and ports: the rule will apply to all ports and protocols.
   TCP: the rule will apply to the specified port and the TCP protocol.
   UDP: the rule will apply to the specified port and the UDP protocol.

In the IP after translation field enter IP adress that will receive data packets from the public IP adress.
(Optional and just for TCP and UDP) In the Port before translation field enter a port that will forward data packets to the specified IP adress.
(Optional and just for TCP and UDP) In the Port after translation field enter a port that will receive data packets from the specified IP adress.
(Optional) Enter a description of the DNAT rule. You can only use numbers, Latin letters, spaces and characters: ?, !, ~, @, #, $, %, ^, ", &, _, , +, *, , ;, :, ,, ., /, \, , `  `, , , , , (, ), `.
Click Add.

Editing DNAT rule



Management console



include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the DNAT tab.
Open the DNAT rule settings with one of the following ways:

   Click moreicon for the rule you need and select pencilicon Edit.
   Click the name of the rule you need and then click pencilicon Edit.

Edit the rule settings:

   Name: the name of the DNAT rule. You can only use numbers, Latin letters, spaces and characters: ?, !, ~, @, #, $, %, ^, ", &, _, , +, *, , ;, :, ,, ., /, \, , `  `, , , , , (, ), `.
   Protocol: the data transfer protocol:

     All protocls and ports: the rule will apply to all ports and protocols.
     TCP: the rule will apply to the specified port and the TCP protocol.
     UDP: the rule will apply to the specified port and the UDP protocol.
   IP after translation: IP adress that will receive data packets from the public IP adress.
   (Optional and just for TCP and UDP) Port before translation: the port that will forward data packets to the specified IP adress.
   (Optional and just for TCP and UDP) Port after translation: the port that will receive data packets from the specified IP adress.
   Description: the description of the DNAT rule. You can only use numbers, Latin letters, spaces and characters: ?, !, ~, @, #, $, %, ^, ", &, _, , +, *, , ;, :, ,, ., /, \, , `  `, , , , , (, ), `.
Click Save changes.

Deleting DNAT rule



Management console



This is a group operation: you can delete several rules at once by setting the checkboxes.

include(/en/_includes/_open_advanced_router.md)

Go to the DNAT tab.
Delete the rule with one of the following ways:

   Click moreicon for the rule you need and select trashicon Delete.
   Set the checkbox for the required rule, then click trashicon Delete above the table.
Confirm the deletion.
description: Adding, editing and deleting rules for redirecting data from a public IP address to an IP address inside a private network.

title: VPN tunnels
data:
You can manage VPN tunnels: view, add or remove them from the project, as well as edit and restart tunnels.

VPN service is available in the Neutron and Sprut SDN. Service management tools depend on SDN used:

Sprut SDN: m interface, API, Terraform.
Neutron SDN: management console interface, API, Terraform, OpenStack CLI.

Viewing a list of VPN tunnels and information about them



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project you need.
Go to Virtual networks → VPN.

   A list of VPN tunnels will appear.

Click the name of a VPN tunnel.

    A page with detailed information about it will open. Navigate between the page tabs to view information about IKE and IPsec settings, endpoint groups, and the tunnel. You can also edit the VPN tunnel settings on this page.




Make sure that:

   OpenStack CLI is installed.
   You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.

To view a list of VPN tunnels, run the command:

      openstack vpn ipsec site connection list

To view detailed information about the VPN tunnel, run the command:

        openstack vpn ipsec site connection show

   General information about the tunnel and identifiers will be displayed:

   IKE Policy — the identifier of the IKE policy. To view detailed information about the policy, run the command:

           openstack vpn ike policy show

   IPSec Policy — the identifier of the IPsec policy. To view detailed information about the policy, run the command:

            openstack vpn ipsec policy show

   Local Endpoint Group ID — the identifier of the local endpoint group. To view detailed information about the group, run the command:

            openstack vpn endpoint group show

   Peer Endpoint Group ID — the identifier of the remote (peer) endpoint group. To view detailed information about the group, run the command:

            openstack vpn endpoint group show

   VPN Service — the identifier of the VPN service that this VPN tunnel serves. To view detailed information about the service, run the command:

            openstack vpn service show


Adding a VPN Tunnel



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project you need.
Go to Virtual networks → VPN.
Click the Add VPN or Add button. The New VPN Tunnel Wizard opens.
Select the SDN in which the VPN will be created:

   SDN Neutron: VPN can only be connected to a standard router of Sprut or Neutron.
   SDN Sprut: VPN can only be connected to an advanced router.

Set up IKE:

   IKE Policy — select an IKE policy from the dropdown list. If the required policy does not exist, create a new one:

       Select New IKE Policy from the dropdown list.
       Set the policy settings:

          Policy name.
          Key lifetime (in seconds).
          Authorization Algorithm — sha256 is recommended.
          Encryption algorithm — aes256 is recommended.
          IKE version — v2 is recommended.
          DiffieHellman group — group14 is recommended.

   Press the Next Step button.

Configure IPsec:

    IPsec policy — select an IPsec policy from the dropdown list. If the required policy does not exist, create a new one:

       Select New IPsec Policy from the dropdown list.
       Set the policy settings:

          Policy name.
          Key lifetime (in seconds).
          Authorization Algorithm — it is recommended to select sha256.
          Encryption algorithm — aes256 is recommended.
          DiffieHellman group — it is recommended to select the group14 group.

    Press the Next Step button.

Set up endpoint groups:

   Router — select the router whose subnets should be accessible through the VPN tunnel. The available options depend on the selected SDN, and only include routers that are connected to an external network and have an assigned external IP address.


       It is recommended to create no more than 500 connections for one router. With more connections, errors may occur.


Select New endpoint group from the dropdown list.

    Set the group settings:

         Neutron
         Sprut


         Name — the name of a local endpoint group.
         Subnets — select one or more subnets connected to the previously selected router. These subnets will be accessible through the VPN tunnel.


         Name — the name of a local endpoint group.
         Subnet address — specify the IP address (CIDR) of the subnet connected to the previously selected router. This subnet will be accessible through the VPN tunnel.
         (Optional) To connect an additional subnet, click Добавить еще один CIDR and specify the IP address of the subnet that should be accessible through the VPN tunnel.


    Remote Endpoint — select a remote endpoint group from the dropdown list. If the required group does not exist, create a new one:

       Select New endpoint group from the dropdown list.
       Set the group settings:

          Group name.
          Subnet address — address of the remote subnet that will be accessible through the VPN tunnel.

            If you need to add more subnets, click the Add subnet link.

    Press the Next Step button.

Set up a VPN tunnel:

    Specify basic settings:

       Tunnel name.
       Public IPv4 address of the peer (Peer IP).
       Shared Key (PSK).

         If necessary, generate a key by clicking the corresponding button.


         Valid characters:
         uppercase and lowercase letters of the Latin alphabet;
         numbers;
         special characters , +, &, !, @, #, $, %, ^, *, (, ), ,, ., :, ;, _, , `, , , /`.

         The key must contain at least one letter or number.


    (Optional) Specify advanced settings:

       Peer Router ID for Authentication (Peer ID) — by default matches the peer address.
       (For VPN in Sprut SDN only) Селектор потоков траффика:

         Объединить — do not split traffic selectors, that is, wrap all address prefixes in one data transmission tunnel.
         Разделить — split traffic selectors, that is, create a separate data transmission tunnel for each pair of address prefixes.

       Initiator State — behavior when establishing an IPsec connection:

         bidirectional (default) — the VK Cloud platform will attempt to establish a connection with a remote peer.
         responseonly — the platform expects a VPN connection to be initiated by a remote peer and does not attempt to establish one on its own.

       Settings for detecting the unavailability of a remote peer (Dead Peer Detection, DPD):

         When a peer is unavailable — determines the behavior of the VK Cloud platform if a remote peer is unavailable:

           hold (default) — When an unreachable IPsec connection is detected, the connection is terminated. The connection can only be reestablished by a remote peer.
           clear — When an unreachable IPsec connection is detected, the connection is terminated. The connection will not be reestablished even if the remote peer attempts to do so.
           restart — When an unreachable IPsec connection is detected, the connection is terminated. The VK Cloud platform will try to reestablish a connection with the remote peer.

         Peer Downtime Detection Interval — at what interval (in seconds) to send test DPD messages.

         Time to detect peer unavailable — if after this timeout (in seconds) no DPD check messages were received from a remote peer, then it is considered unavailable (dead).

           The default value for this setting is four times the Peer Downtime Detection Interval.

Click the Create VPN Tunnel button.




Make sure that:

    OpenStack CLI is installed.
    You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.

Set up IKE:

   Get a list of IKE policies and view policy details:

              openstack vpn ike policy list

              openstack vpn ike policy show

      Save the policy ID (id) that will be used by the VPN tunnel.

   If a suitable IKE policy was not found in the previous step, create it:

       Linux/macOS (bash, zsh)
       Windows (PowerShell)


              openstack vpn ike policy create  \
         lifetime units,value \
         authalgorithm  \
         encryptionalgorithm  \
         ikeversion  \
         pfs


             openstack vpn ike policy create  `
         lifetime units,value `
         authalgorithm  `
         encryptionalgorithm  `
         ikeversion  `
         pfs


      After creation, information about the created object will be displayed, including its identifier. Save the policy ID (id) that will be used by the VPN tunnel.

Set up IPsec:

   Get a list of IPsec policies and view policy details:

              openstack vpn ipsec policy list

              openstack vpn ipsec policy show

       Make a note of the policy ID that will be used by the VPN tunnel.

   If a suitable IPsec policy was not found in the previous step, create it:

       Linux/macOS (bash, zsh)
       Windows (PowerShell)


              openstack vpn ipsec policy create  \
         lifetime units,value \
         authalgorithm  \
         encryptionalgorithm  \
         pfs


            openstack vpn ipsec policy create  `
        lifetime units,value `
        authalgorithm  `
        encryptionalgorithm  `
        pfs


      After creation, information about the created object will be displayed, including its identifier. Make a note of the policy ID that will be used by the VPN tunnel.

Create a VPN service that will serve the VPN tunnel:

   Get a list of routers and view detailed information about them:

              open stack router list

              openstack router show

       Write down the ID of the router whose subnets you want to make available through the VPN tunnel.

       Such a router must have access to the Internet and an external IP address associated with it.

   Create a VPN service using this router:

      Linux/macOS (bash, zsh)
      Windows (PowerShell)


            openstack vpn service create  \
        router  \
        enable


            openstack vpn service create  `
        router  `
        enable


      After creation, information about the created object will be displayed, including its identifier. Make a note of the VPN service ID that will be used by the VPN tunnel.

Set up endpoint groups:

   Get a list of endpoint groups and view detailed information about them:

              openstack vpn endpoint group list

              openstack vpn endpoint group show

       Write down:
       ID of the group that will be used by the VPN tunnel as the local endpoint group. Such a group must be of type subnet.

         The subnets belonging to the group must be connected to the router that was specified in the previous step in the VPN service settings.

       ID of the group that will be used by the VPN tunnel as the remote endpoint group. Such a group must be of type cidr.

   If there is no suitable local endpoint group, create it:

      Linux/macOS (bash, zsh)
      Windows (PowerShell)


             openstack vpn endpoint group create  \
         type subnet \
         value  \
         ...
         value


             openstack vpn endpoint group create  `
         type subnet `
         value  `
         ...
         value


      After creation, information about the created object will be displayed, including its identifier. Write down the ID of the local endpoint group that will be used by the VPN tunnel.

   If there is no suitable remote endpoint group, create it:

      Linux/macOS (bash, zsh)
      Windows (PowerShell)


             openstack vpn endpoint group create  \
         type cidr \
         value "" \
         ...
         value ""


             openstack vpn endpoint group create  `
         type cidr `
         value "" `
         ...
         value ""


      After creation, information about the created object will be displayed, including its identifier. Write down the ID of the remote endpoint group that will be used by the VPN tunnel.

Create a VPN tunnel:

   Linux/macOS (bash, zsh)
   Windows (PowerShell)


       openstack vpn ipsec site connection create  \
      dpd action,interval,timeout  \
      initiator  \
      peeraddress "" \
      peerid "" \
      ikepolicy  \
      ipsecpolicy  \
      vpnservice  \
      localendpointgroup  \
      peerendpointgroup  \
      psk "" \
      enable


       openstack vpn ipsec site connection create  `
      dpd action,interval,timeout  `
      initiator  `
      peeraddress "" `
      peerid "" `
      ikepolicy  `
      ipsecpolicy  `
      vpnservice  `
      localendpointgroup  `
      peerendpointgroup  `
      psk "" `
      enable


Editing a VPN Tunnel



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project you need.
Go to Virtual networks → VPN.
Click   for the required VPN tunnel and select Edit VPN.
If necessary, edit the local or remote endpoint group:

   Local Endpoint — select a local endpoint group from the dropdown list. If the required group does not exist, create a new one:

       Select New endpoint group from the dropdown list.
       Set the group settings:

         Neutron
         Sprut


         Name — the name of a local endpoint group.
         Subnets — select one or more subnets connected to the previously selected router. These subnets will be accessible through the VPN tunnel.


         Name — the name of a local endpoint group.
         Subnet address — specify the IP address (CIDR) of the subnet connected to the previously selected router. This subnet will be accessible through the VPN tunnel.
         (Optional) To connect an additional subnet, click Добавить еще один CIDR and specify the IP address of the subnet that should be accessible through the VPN tunnel.


   Remote Endpoint — select a remote endpoint group from the dropdown list. If the required group does not exist, create a new one:

       Select New endpoint group from the dropdown list.
       Set the group settings:

          Group name.
          Subnet address — address of the remote subnet that will be accessible through the VPN tunnel.

            If you need to add more subnets, click the Add subnet link.

Press the Next Step button.
Edit the VPN tunnel settings:

   Basic settings:

       Tunnel name.
       Public IPv4 address of the peer (Peer IP).
       Shared Key (PSK).

         If necessary, generate a key by clicking the corresponding button.


         Valid characters:
         uppercase and lowercase Latin letters;
         numbers;
         special characters , +, &, !, @, #, $, %, ^, *, (, ), ,, ., :, ;, _, , `, , , /`.

         The key must contain at least one letter or number.


   (Optional) Аdvanced settings:

      Peer Router ID for Authentication (Peer ID) — by default matches the peer address.
      (For VPN in Sprut SDN only) Селектор потоков траффика:

         Объединить — do not split traffic selectors, that is, wrap all address prefixes in one data transmission tunnel.
         Разделить — split traffic selectors, that is, create a separate data transmission tunnel for each pair of address prefixes.

      Initiator State — behavior when establishing an IPsec connection:

         bidirectional (default) — the VK Cloud platform will attempt to establish a connection with a remote peer.
         responseonly — the platform expects a VPN connection to be initiated by a remote peer and does not attempt to establish one on its own.

      Settings for detecting the unavailability of a remote peer (Dead Peer Detection, DPD):

         When a peer is unavailable — determines the behavior of the VK Cloud platform if a remote peer is unavailable:

           hold (default) — when an unreachable IPsec connection is detected, the connection is terminated. The connection can only be reestablished by a remote peer.
           clear — when an unreachable IPsec connection is detected, the connection is terminated. The connection will not be reestablished even if the remote peer attempts to do so.
           restart — when an unreachable IPsec connection is detected, the connection is terminated. The VK Cloud platform will try to reestablish the connection with the remote peer.

         Peer Downtime Detection Interval — the interval (in seconds) at which to send DPD test messages.

         Time to detect peer unavailable — if during this interval (in seconds) no DPD test messages were received from a remote peer, then it is considered unavailable (dead).

           The default value for this setting is four times the Peer Downtime Detection Interval.

Click the Save button.




Make sure that:

    OpenStack CLI is installed.
    You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.

View detailed information about the VPN tunnel you want to edit.

(If necessary) select other endpoint groups or create new ones:

   Get a list of endpoint groups and view detailed information about them:

            openstack vpn endpoint group list

            openstack vpn endpoint group show

      Write down:

      ID of the group that will be used by the VPN tunnel as the local endpoint group. Such a group must be of type subnet.

         The subnets belonging to the group must be connected to the router that was specified in the previous step in the VPN service settings.

      ID of the group that will be used by the VPN tunnel as the remote endpoint group. Such a group must be of type cidr.

   If there is no suitable local endpoint group, create it:

      Linux/macOS (bash, zsh)
      Windows (PowerShell)


            openstack vpn endpoint group create  \
      type subnet \
      value  \
      ...
      value


             openstack vpn endpoint group create  `
         type subnet `
         value  `
         ...
         value


      After creation, information about the created object will be displayed, including its identifier. Write down the ID of the local endpoint group that will be used by the VPN tunnel.

   If there is no suitable remote endpoint group, create it:

             openstack vpn endpoint group create  \

      After creation, information about the created object will be displayed, including its identifier. Write down the ID of the remote endpoint group that will be used by the VPN tunnel.

Edit the VPN tunnel settings:

   Linux/macOS (bash, zsh)
   Windows (PowerShell)


       openstack vpn ipsec site connection set  \
      name  \
      dpd action,interval,timeout  \
      initiator  \
      peeraddress "" \
      peerid "" \
      localendpointgroup  \
      peerendpointgroup  \
      enable


       openstack vpn ipsec site connection set  `
      name  `
      dpd action,interval,timeout  `
      initiator  `
      peeraddress "" `
      peerid "" `
      localendpointgroup  `
      peerendpointgroup  `
      enable


Restarting a VPN tunnel



Restarting the VPN tunnel is only available for VPNs in SDN Neutron. In SDN Sprut, all tunnel changes are applied automatically, no restart is required.





Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project you need.
Go to Virtual networks → VPN.
Click   for the required VPN tunnel and select Restart VPN.
Read the warning.
Press the Restart button.




Make sure that:

    OpenStack CLI is installed.
    You can authorize in the OpenStack CLI.

View detailed information about the VPN tunnel that needs to be restarted.

Run the command:

   Linux/macOS (bash, zsh)
   Windows (PowerShell)


       openstack vpn service set  disable && openstack vpn service set  enable


       openstack vpn service set  disable; openstack vpn service set  enable


Removing a VPN tunnel



Management console
OpenStack CLI



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project you need.
Go to Virtual networks → VPN.
Click   for the required VPN tunnel and select Remove VPN.
Review the list of objects to be deleted.

Click the Confirm button.

    OpenStack CLI is installed.

Look at the list of VPN tunnels and find the ID of the tunnel you want to remove.

title: Viewing Topology
data:
A network topology is a diagram of the network connectivity of virtual machines. It shows the following elements, as well as all the links between them:

networks;
subnets;
routers;
virtual machines.

To view the network topology of an individual project:

Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project.
Go to Virtual networks → Network topology.

Topology management

Available network topology operations:

Move. Use the arrows in the upper right corner or hold the left mouse button and move the diagram in the required direction.
Scaling. Use + and  in the upper right corner of the diagram or scroll with the mouse wheel.
Hide or show signatures. Use the Show labels switch in the upper left corner of the diagram.
View item details. Click on the schematic element with the left mouse button. Options will be displayed:

  Name — name of the selected element.
  ID — element identifier in the system.
  Type — type of the selected element:

    network;
    subnet;
    instance;
    router;
    balancer;
    port.

  Status — state of the selected element. Not shown for subnet.

  Additional options depending on the element type.
  Link to go to the item in your account. Not displayed for ports.
description: Viewing the topology of virtual networks using VK Cloud tools.

title: Setting up a VPN tunnel
data:
The VPN service is only available in networks created with use of Neutron SDN.



Throughout this guide, an VK Cloud subnet will be connected with the client subnet via a VPN tunnel. This VPN tunnel will be built to another network of the VK Cloud platform, and a virtual machine will be used as a VPN endpoint. Several virtual machines will also be created to test the functionality of the tunnel.

The guide can be adapted to work with any other VPN endpoint, such as a corporate firewall or other network equipment.

1. Preparatory steps

Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

Create networks.


   You can create a network with any parameters you choose. Adjust the next steps in this scenario as needed.

   Client network
   Virtual network


   This network will act as the client network.

   When creating a network, set the following parameters:

    Network name: clientNet.
    Internet Access: Make sure this option is selected. It will allow you to assign public floating IP addresses to virtual machines on this network.
    Router: Create new.
    Subnet List: edit the only subnet in the list. Set the following parameters for the subnet:

      Name: clientSubnet.
      Address: 172.16.0.0/29.
      Gateway: 172.16.0.1.
      Enable DHCP: Make sure this option is selected.
      DHCP IP address pool: 172.16.0.2  172.16.0.6.
      Private DNS: Make sure this option is selected.


    This network will act as a virtual network.

    When creating a network, set the following parameters:

    Network name: vkcloudNet.
    Internet Access: Make sure this option is selected. It will allow you to ensure the operation of the VPN tunnel and assign public floating IP addresses to virtual machines in this network.
    Router: Create new.
    Subnet List: edit the only subnet in the list. Set the following parameters for the subnet:

      Name: vkcloudSubnet.
      Address: 10.0.0.0/29.
      Gateway: 10.0.0.1.
      Enable DHCP: Make sure this option is selected.
      DHCP IP address pool: 10.0.0.2  10.0.0.6.
      Private DNS: Make sure this option is selected.


Determine which routers have been created for these networks. This information will be needed when you configure the VPN further.

    It is further assumed that:

    router router_1234 was created for the clientNet network;
    router router_5678 was created for the vkcloudNet network.

Determine the IP address of the SNAT interface for the router_5678 router:

    Open the page with the list of subnets for the vkcloudNet network.
    Click on the subnet name vkcloudSubnet.
    Click the Ports tab.
    Find the SNAT device port in the list of ports and copy its IP address.

Create a virtual machine that will act as a VPN gateway on the clientNet client network, with the following settings:

    Virtual machine name: client_vpn_gw.
    Virtual machine type: STD212.
    Number of machines in the configuration: one.
    Operating system: Ubuntu 22.04.
    Network: client network and corresponding clientNet: clientSubnet subnet.
    Virtual Machine Key: The key that will be used to connect via SSH.
    Firewall settings: everything is allowed (all).
    Assign External IP: Make sure this option is selected.

   Select other parameters of the virtual machine at your discretion.

Collect information necessary for further work. Further, it is assumed that:

    Object                                                                Value           
       
    The public IP address of the router router_5678                     192.0.2.100   
    IP address of the client_vpn_gw virtual machine on the clientSubnet subnet  172.16.0.5 
    Floating public IP address of the virtual machine client_vpn_gw     192.0.2.200   
    Client subnet from client VPN gateway client_vpn_gw                 172.16.0.0/29 
    Cloud VPN Gateway Virtual Subnet                                      10.0.0.0/29   
    IP address of the SNAT port in the cloud subnet                     10.0.0.5      

Example InfrastructureparamsnoBordertrue

2. Set up a VPN tunnel on the cloud side

Create a VPN with the following settings:



1. Setting up IKE
2. Configuring IPsec
3. Creating Endpoint Groups
4. Tunnel setup



Select IKE Policy  New IKE Policy, and set:

Policy name**: vkcloudclientike.
Key lifetime**: 3600 seconds.
Authorization Algorithm**: sha256.
Encryption algorithm**: aes256.
IKE version**: v2.
DiffieHellman group**: group14.




Select IPsec Policy  New IPsec Policy, and set:

Policy name**: vkcloudclientipsec.
Key lifetime**: 3600 seconds.
Authorization Algorithm**: sha256.
Encryption algorithm**: aes256.
DiffieHellman group**: group14.




Choose:

Router**: router_5678.

Local Endpoint**: New endpoint group.
  Name: vkcloudendpointgroup.
  Subnets: vkcloudSubnet.

Remote Endpoint**: New endpoint group.
  Group name: clientendpointgroup.
  Subnet address: 172.16.0.0/29.




Select Settings  Basic, and set:

Tunnel name**: vkcloudclientvpn.
Public IPv4 Peer IP address**: 192.0.2.200.
Shared Key (PSK)**: Any preshared key of your choice that satisfies the key requirements.

  The key must:

  be at least 16 characters long;
  contain at least one letter or number;
  consist only of the following valid characters:
    uppercase and lowercase letters of the Latin alphabet;
    numbers;
    special characters , +, &, !, @, #, $, %, ^, *, (, ), ,, ., :, ;, _, , `, , , /`.

3. Set up a VPN tunnel on the side of the client network

Disable IP Source Guard on the VPN gateway port so that it can forward any traffic:

    Find the port with the private IP address 172.16.0.5 of the virtual machine client_vpn_gw. Get the ID of this port.

    Allow traffic from any address through this port:

              openstack port set  allowedaddress ipaddress0.0.0.0/0

Connect to the client_vpn_gw virtual machine via SSH. All further actions must be performed on this virtual machine.

Enable IP Forwarding so that the virtual machine can route traffic from the private network to the VPN tunnel:

        echo 'net.ipv4.ip_forward  1'  sudo tee a /etc/sysctl.conf
    sudo sysctl p

Install StrongSwan  An IPsec VPN Implementation for Linux:

      sudo apt update
   sudo apt install y strongswan libcharonextraplugins libcharonextauthplugins libstrongswanextraplugins

Add VPN connection settings from the client network side to the /etc/ipsec.conf file. These settings are a mirror image of the tunnel settings made in the previous step.

      conn clientvkcloudvpn
      authbysecret
      left%defaultroute
      leftid192.0.2.200
      leftsubnet172.16.0.0/29
      right192.0.2.100
      rightsubnet10.0.0.0/29
      ikeaes256sha2_256modp2048!
      espaes256sha2_256!
      keyingtries0
      ikelifetime3600
      lifetime8h
      dpddelay30
      dpdtimeout120
      dpdactionhold
      autostart


   For the DiffieHellman group group14, the equivalent notation is modp_2048. The mapping of modp to group names is given in RFC 3526.


Specify the shared key (PSK) in the /etc/ipsec.secrets file. The key must match the key specified previously:

      192.0.2.200 192.0.2.100 : PSK ""

Restart the StrongSwan service:

      sudo systemctl restart strongswanstarter

4. Add static routes

In order for traffic to pass through the VPN tunnel, you need to add static routes:



On the side of the cloud network
On the side of the client network



Open the page with the list of subnets for the vkcloudNet network in your management console.
Expand the vkcloudSubnet subnet menu and select Edit Subnet.
Make sure the Show static routes field option is selected.
Enter a static route to the client network 172.16.0.0/29 in the field. As the next hop, you need to specify the IP address of the SNAT interface of the router router_5678 in the cloud subnet vkcloudSubnet.

      172.16.0.0/29  10.0.0.5


Open the page with information about the router router_1234 in your management console, to which the client subnet clientSubnet and the VPN gateway client_vpn_gw are connected.
On the Static Routes tab, click the Add Static Route button.
Write a static route to the cloud network 10.0.0.0/29:

    Destination network: 10.0.0.0/29.
    Intermediate host (Next HOP): 172.16.0.5 (IP address of the VPN gateway on the client subnet).

Click the Add route button.

5. Check if the VPN tunnel is working

View the status of the VPN tunnel from the VK Cloud platform.

    To do this, open the VPN page vkcloudclientvpn in your management console and go to the Tunnel Settings tab. The VPN must be in ACTIVE status.

Create a firewall rule group icmp to allow ICMP traffic.

    In this group, create an inbound rule:

    Type: ICMP.
    Remote address: All IP addresses.

    This is necessary so that the test virtual machines can ping each other.

Create two virtual machines:

    clientVM:

      in the network clientNet, subnet clientSubnet;
      with a floating IP address to connect to it via SSH;
      with firewall rule groups default, ssh, icmp.

    vkcloudVM:
      in the network vkcloudNet, subnet vkcloudSubnet;
      with a floating IP address to connect to it via SSH;
      with firewall rule groups default, ssh, icmp.

Determine the private IP addresses of the virtual machines on the respective subnets. Let be:

    clientVM has IP address 172.16.0.4;
    vkcloudVM has IP address 10.0.0.4.

Connect to the vkcloudVM virtual machine via SSH.

Ping the clientVM virtual machine from the vkcloudVM virtual machine:

        ping 172.16.0.4

    The clientVM host must respond to the ping.

Delete unused resources

If you no longer need the created resources, delete them:

Delete virtual machines.
Delete VPN tunnel.
Delete static routes defined on the side of the client network.


   Static routes on the side of the cloud network will be deleted along with the subnet for which they were registered.


Delete client and cloud network routers.
Delete the client and cloud subnets and networks.
Delete floating IP addresses.
description: VPN allows you to connect the VK Cloud cloud network with an external (client) network. An example will be shown here on how to organize the interaction of a cloud network with a client network via a VPN.

title: Organizing a virtual IP address
data:
If incoming traffic is processed by a cluster of several similar virtual machines, then you can create a virtual IP address (Virtual IP, VIP) for them. This address is used to organize faulttolerant processing of incoming traffic by these virtual machines. The technology works like this: a VIP is assigned to one of the cluster virtual machines that processes traffic from this VIP. Clients accessing this address will be directed to this virtual machine. If the virtual machine fails, then the VIP will be transferred to another virtual machine from the cluster, and traffic processing will continue. Virtual machines monitor their state and manage VIP assignment using the VRRP protocol (https://www.rfceditor.org/rfc/rfc3768).

To show the virtual IP address setting:

two virtual machines will be created for which:
  a virtual IP address will be created;
  VRRP will be configured in the keepalived implementation to serve this IP address.
a third virtual machine with a floating IP address will be created, from which all the necessary settings and health check will be performed.

Scenario DiagramparamsnoBordertrue

1. Preparation steps

Make sure OpenStack CLI is installed. Also check that you can sign in the OpenStack CLI.

Select the subnet where the virtual machines and virtual IP address will be placed. They must be on the same subnet.

    If the required subnet does not exist, create it.

    Write down the following information:
    subnet name;
    the name of the network in which the subnet is located.

    The mysubnet subnet in the mynetwork network will be used as an example.

Determine which IP address will be used as the virtual IP address. This IP address must not be used by any entities (such as a virtual machine or load balancer).

    The address 192.168.0.254/24 will be used as an example.

Make sure that this IP address will not be used by other objects (for example, assigned to a virtual machine or load balancer port). One of the easiest ways to achieve this is to create an OpenStack port with a chosen address and then never use that port anywhere.

    To create such a port, run the command in the OpenStack CLI:

        openstack port create  network mynetwork fixedip subnetmysubnet,ipaddress192.168.0.254

Create the kldvm1, kldvm2 and kldjumphostvm virtual machines.

    These VMs must be in a security group that allows all inbound and outbound traffic within the group itself.
    For example, such a group is default.

    If nonstandard security groups are used, they must allow:
    SSH traffic to kldvm1 and kldvm2;
    VRRP traffic between kldvm1 and kldvm2;
    ICMP traffic to the selected virtual IP address (for health check).

   kldvm1
   kldvm2
   kldjumphostvm


   Set the following options:

   Virtual machine name: kldvm1.
   Number of machines in configuration: 1.
   Operating system: Ubuntu 22.04.
   Network: network and subnet selected earlier.
   DNSname: kldvm1.
   Firewall settings: default.
   Assign external IP: make sure the option is not selected.

   Select other parameters of the virtual machine at your discretion.


   Set the following options:

   Virtual machine name: kldvm2.
   Number of machines in configuration: 1.
   Operating system: Ubuntu 22.04.
   Network: network and subnet selected earlier.
   DNSname: kldvm2.
   Firewall settings: default.
   Assign external IP: make sure the option is not selected.

   Select other parameters of the virtual machine at your discretion.


   Set the following options:

    Virtual machine name: kldjumphostvm.
    Number of machines in configuration: 1.
    Operating system: Ubuntu 22.04.
    Network: network and subnet selected earlier.
    DNSname: kldjumphostvm.
    Firewall settings: default, ssh.
    Assign external IP: make sure the option is selected. A floating IP address (Floating IP, FIP) is required to connect to a virtual machine via SSH from the Internet.

    Select other parameters of the virtual machine at your discretion.


Define the OpenStack port through which the kldvm1 and kldvm2 virtual machines will work with the virtual IP address:

    For the virtual machine kldvm1:

       Connect to the kldjumphostvm virtual machine via SSH.
       Connect to the virtual machine kldvm1 via SSH.
       Run the command:

                    ip route  grep default

          Sample output:

                    default via 192.168.0.1 dev ens3 proto dhcp src 192.168.0.11 metric 100

          Record the following information from the output:

          Network interface name (followed by dev): in this example ens3.
          IP address of the network interface (followed by src): in this example 192.168.0.11.

       Run the OpenStack CLI command:

                  openstack port list c ID server kldvm1 fixedip ipaddress

         Sample output:

                  ++
          ID                                   
         ++
          e1bd636aaaaabbbbcccca673e7cbef83 
         ++

         Record the OpenStack port ID from the output.

    Follow the same steps on the kldvm2 virtual machine.

Write down all received data. Result for the given example:


 Object                                                     Value                                     
    
 For kldvm1 virtual machine                                                                      
 Network interface name                                     ens3                                    
 Network interface IP address                               192.168.0.11                            
 OpenStack port ID for the network interface                e1bd636aaaaabbbbcccca673e7cbef83    
 For kldvm2 virtual machine                                                                      
 Network interface name                                     ens3                                    
 Network interface IP address                               192.168.0.22                            
 OpenStack port ID for the network interface                74268d00xxxxyyyyzzzzcf9f93536d5c    
 Other                                                                                             
 Subnet for virtual machines and virtual IP address         192.168.0.0/24                          
 Subnet name                                                mysubnet                                
 The name of the network where the subnet is located        mynetwork                               
 Virtual IP address                                         192.168.0.254/24                        

2. Install and configure keepalived

Install keepalived:

    For the virtual machine kldvm1:

       Connect to the kldjumphostvm virtual machine via SSH.
       Connect to the virtual machine kldvm1 via SSH.
       Run the commands:

                    sudo apt update
          sudo apt install keepalived

    Follow the same steps on the kldvm2 virtual machine.

Configure keepalived:

   kldvm1
   kldvm2


   Connect to the kldjumphostvm virtual machine via SSH.
   Connect to the virtual machine kldvm1 via SSH.
   Edit the /etc/keepalived/keepalived.conf file, replacing its contents with the following:

            global_defs
      
        router_id KLDVM1
      

      vrrp_instance VI_254
      
        state MASTER
        interface ens3
        virtual_router_id 254
        priority 120
        advert_int 1

        authentication
        
          auth_type PASS
          auth_pass
        

        virtual_ipaddress
        
          192.168.0.254/24
        
      


   Connect to the kldjumphostvm virtual machine via SSH.
   Connect to the virtual machine kldvm2 via SSH.
   Edit the /etc/keepalived/keepalived.conf file, replacing its contents with the following:

            global_defs
      
        router_id KLDVM2
      

      vrrp_instance VI_254
      
        state BACKUP
        interface ens3
        virtual_router_id 254
        priority 90
        advert_int 1

        authentication
        
          auth_type PASS
          auth_pass
        

        virtual_ipaddress
        
          192.168.0.254/24
        
      


   In the config file:

    router_id — identifier of the keepalived router, the value is different for each of the configurations.
    vrrp_instance  VRRP instance settings. The VRRP instance name is only locally significant, so it can be the same for configurations on different virtual machines.

      state is the role that keepalived starts with: MASTER or SLAVE. Then, depending on the result of the selection of the master, the role can be changed.
      interface is the name of the interface on which VRRP is running. The interface name is only locally significant, so it can be the same for configurations on different virtual machines.
      virtual_router_id — VRRP router ID from 0 to 255. Must match in both configurations.
      priority  the priority according to which the VRRP master is selected. In this case, kldvm1 will be the master because it has the highest priority.
      advert_int — VRRP message sending interval (in seconds).
      authentication — authentication parameters. In this case, authentication is performed using a password (PASS). Passwords (value auth_pass) must match in all configurations.
      virtual_ipaddress  virtual IP address. The values must match in all configurations.

      Read more about the parameters in the keepalived documentation.

Run keepalived:

    For the virtual machine kldvm1:

       Connect to the kldjumphostvm virtual machine via SSH.
       Connect to the virtual machine kldvm1 via SSH.
       Run the command:

                  sudo systemctl start keepalived

       Run the command to check the status of keepalived:

                  sudo systemctl status keepalived

         Example output:

                  ● keepalived.service  Keepalive Daemon (LVS and VRRP)
              Loaded: loaded (/lib/systemd/system/keepalived.service; enabled; vendor preset: enabled)
              Active: active (running) since Mon 20230109 10:55:35 UTC; 21h ago
              ...

         keepalived must be in the running state.

    Follow the same steps on the kldvm2 virtual machine.

3. Configure IP Source Guard

The keepalived installed on virtual machines should be able to send traffic not only from the IP addresses 192.168.0.11 and 192.168.0.22, but also from the virtual IP address 192.168.0.254. Since OpenStack ports in VK Cloud use the IP Source Guard mechanism, allow traffic from the virtual IP address for virtual machine ports:

For kldvm1:

      openstack port set e1bd636aaaaabbbbcccca673e7cbef83 allowedaddress ipaddress192.168.0.254/24

For kldvm2:

      openstack port set 74268d00xxxxyyyyzzzzcf9f93536d5c allowedaddress ipaddress192.168.0.254/24

4. Check if the virtual IP address is working

Open two terminal sessions:

During the first session:
   Connect to the virtual machine kldjumphostvm via SSH.
   Start a continuous ping of the virtual IP address:

            ping 192.168.0.254

      The IP address should successfully ping.

In the second session:

    Connect to the kldjumphostvm virtual machine via SSH.
    Connect to the virtual machine kldvm1 via SSH.
    Stop the keepalived process:

            sudo systemctl stop keepalived

      Since this virtual machine was in the role of master and stopped processing traffic, now the processing of traffic arriving at the virtual IP address will be transferred to the virtual machine kldvm2.
      The ping process started in the first terminal session should not be interrupted.

   Restart the keepalived process:

              sudo systemctl start keepalived

       The virtual machine will again assume the role of master and begin processing traffic that arrives at the virtual IP address.

   Run the command:

            ip address show dev ens3

      Check that the virtual IP address is present in the output:

            ens3:  mtu 1500 qdisc fq_codel state UP group default qlen 1000
          link/ether fa:16:3e:a3:82:f2 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
          altname enp0s3
          inet 192.168.0.4/24 metric 100 brd 192.168.0.255 scope global dynamic ens3
             valid_lft 523420sec preferred_lft 523420sec
          inet 192.168.0.254/24 scope global secondary ens3
             valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever

Delete unused resources

If you no longer need the created resources, delete them:

Delete virtual machines.
Remove the floating IP address assigned to the kldjumphostvm virtual machine.
Delete the port that has been assigned a virtual IP address.
Delete the subnet and network where the virtual cars.
description: Multiple virtual machines can share the same clustered IP address using the VRRP protocol. When using a configuration with this IP address, if the virtual machine that processes traffic from this address fails, the traffic will be redirected to one of the remaining virtual machines.

title: Tariffication
data:
About tariffication

Tariffication is based on the "pay as you go" principle: you are charged only for the resources you consume to the nearest second.

The cost of network services is given in price list. You can use calculator to calculate the total cost of other platform services that use network services. See Billing for how the tools related to paying for platform services work.

What is charged

The cost of these resources is displayed in your personal VK Cloud account as part of the total cost of the services that use them.

Charged:

Public IP addresses:
  The public IP address assigned to the port if the port is connected to the `extnet' network.
  Existing floating public IP addresses (even if not assigned to any port).

Standard and service load balancers.

What is not charged

The public IP address assigned to the router when you select the External network connection option.

  This allows, for example, virtual machines to access the Internet without having to purchase floating IP addresses.
  However, you cannot use such an IP address to access virtual machines from the Internet. A floating IP address will be required.

Incoming and outgoing traffic.
Using a VPN.
