title: Connecting to cluster using Kubernetes Dashboard
data:
Kubernetes Dashboard is a universal web interface for Kubernetes clusters available into all VK Cloud clusters. It allows users to manage both the cluster itself and the applications running in it. Read more in official Kubernetes documentation.

The way to connect to Kubernetes Dashboard depends on the IP address of the cluster:

If an external IP address is assigned to the cluster, then you can connect from any host with Internet access.
If the cluster is assigned only an internal IP address, then you can connect only from a host in VK Cloud — a virtual machine that is located in the same subnet as the cluster.

To connect to Kubernetes Dashboard, a browser must be installed on the host.

Preparatory steps

Make sure that you can connect to the cluster using kubectl.

On the host from which you plan to connect to the cluster, install kauthproxy if the utility is not already installed:

   Download the archive of the correct version from release page:

      for Linux: kauthproxy_linux_....zip;
      for macOS: kauthproxy_darwin....zip;
      For Windows: kauthproxy_windows....zip.

   Unpack the archive.

   Place the executable file in the directory contained in the PATH environment variable, for example:

      in /usr/local/bin for Linux/macOS;
      In C:\ for Windows.

Connect to cluster



Version of Kubernetes 1.23 and higher
Version of Kubernetes 1.22 and lower



On the host in a separate terminal session, run the command:

      kauthproxy n kubernetesdashboard https://kubernetesdashboard.svc


   Do not close this terminal session, or you will lose access to the Kubernetes Dashboard web interface.


Enter the password for your personal VK Cloud account, if it is not present in the kubeconfig configuration file.

   kauthproxy will periodically ask for this password again.

   The browser will open and you will be directed to the Kubernetes Dashboard web interface.




Get the secret:

   Go to management console VK Cloud under the account of the user who will connect to the cluster.
   Select the project where the required cluster is located.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
   Click   for the required cluster and select Get Secret to enter Kubernetes Dashboard.
   Click the Copy button.

      The secret will be copied to the clipboard.

On the host in a separate terminal session, run the command:

          kauthproxy n kubesystem https://kubernetesdashboard.svc


   Do not close this terminal session, otherwise you will lose access to the Kubernetes Dashboard web interface.


   The browser will open and you will be directed to the Kubernetes Dashboard authorization page.

Select the Token option and paste the previously copied secret.

Click the Sign In button.

   The Kubernetes Dashboard web interface will open.
description: How to connect to a Kubernetes cluster using Kubernetes Dashboard.

title: Connecting to Docker Registry
data:
You can connect to the Docker registry if the appropriate addon is installed in the cluster.

When installing an addon, a standard load balancer with a floating IP address is created for it. Therefore, you can connect to the Docker registry from any host that has Internet access.

Preparatory steps

Make sure that the Docker registry addon (dockerregistry) is installed in the cluster.
Make sure that you can connect to the cluster using kubectl.
Get the data to access the Docker registry.

Connecting to the Docker Registry

On the host from which you plan to connect to the registry:

Install Docker Engine if not already installed. There is a choice of either Docker Desktop or a serverside version of Docker Engine without a GUI.

   Docker Engine must be installed on the host from which the registry will be used. Perform the next steps on that host.

Add the Docker registry to the list of trusted registries:

   Add the insecureregistries parameter with the address of the Docker registry endpoint to the Docker daemon.json configuration file.

      The address is specified in the format :.

            
        ...

         "insecureregistries": 
          "https://192.0.2.2:5000"
        ,

        ...
      

      The location of this file for different Docker Engine installations is given in official Docker documentation.

   Restart the Docker Engine.

      Linux
      Windows
      macOS


      For the server version of the Docker Engine, run one of the commands to restart:

                sudo systemd restart docker

                sudo service docker restart

      For Docker Desktop, use GUI.


      Use GUI Docker Desktop.


      Use GUI Docker Desktop.


Sign in into the registry:

      docker login  username

   Enter the password for the Docker registry.

Now you can do any operations with the registry, for example, to push Docker images there.

Read more about registry operations in official Docker documentation.

Using Docker registry in Kubernetes cluster

In order to deploy workloads in a cluster using images from the Docker registry:

Create the k8sregistrycreds secret which contains the data to access the registry:

   If the namespace parameter is not provided, then the secret will be created in the default namespace (default).


   The secret must reside in the same namespace the workload is planned to be deployed in.

   Linux (bash) / macOS (zsh)
   Windows (PowerShell)


      kubectl create secret dockerregistry k8sregistrycreds \
     dockerserver:5000 \
     dockerusername \
     dockerpassword \
     namespace


      kubectl create secret dockerregistry k8sregistrycreds `
     dockerserver:5000 `
     dockerusername `
     dockerpassword `
     namespace


Specify in the workload manifest:

   Name of the created secret in the ìmagePullSecrets parameter.

   Path to the image from the registry in the containers.image parameter.

     The path should be specified in the :5000//: format.

   Examples of manifests:

   Pod
   Deployment
   ReplicaSet
   StatefulSet
   DaemonSet
   Job
   CronJob


      apiVersion: v1
   kind: Pod
   metadata:
     name: myapp
   spec:
     imagePullSecrets:
     name: k8sregistrycreds
     containers:
     name: myapp
       image: :5000//:


      apiVersion: apps/v1
   kind: Deployment
   metadata:
     name: myapp
   spec:
     template:
       spec:
         imagePullSecrets:
         name: k8sregistrycreds
         containers:
         name: myapp
           image: :5000//:


      apiVersion: apps/v1
   kind: ReplicaSet
   metadata:
     name: myapp
   spec:
     template:
       spec:
         imagePullSecrets:
         name: k8sregistrycreds
         containers:
         name: myapp
           image: :5000//:


      apiVersion: apps/v1
   kind: StatefulSet
   metadata:
     name: myapp
   spec:
     template:
       spec:
         imagePullSecrets:
         name: k8sregistrycreds
         containers:
         name: myapp
           image: :5000//:


      apiVersion: apps/v1
   kind: DaemonSet
   metadata:
     name: myapp
   spec:
     template:
       spec:
         imagePullSecrets:
         name: k8sregistrycreds
         containers:
         name: myapp
           image: :5000//:


      apiVersion: batch/v1
   kind: Job
   metadata:
     name: myapp
   spec:
     template:
       spec:
         imagePullSecrets:
         name: k8sregistrycreds
         containers:
         name: myapp
           image: :5000//:


      apiVersion: batch/v1
   kind: CronJob
   metadata:
     name: myapp
   spec:
     jobTemplate:
       spec:
         template:
           spec:
             imagePullSecrets:
             name: k8sregistrycreds
             containers:
             name: myapp
               image: :5000//:
description: If the Kubernetes cluster has the Docker registry enabled, you can connect to the registry using the procedure described here.

title: Connecting to add-on web interfaces
data:
Some addons that can be installed in the cluster have a web interface. The method of connecting to the web interface depends on the IP address of the cluster:

If an external IP address is assigned to the cluster, then you can connect from any host with Internet access.
If the cluster is assigned only an internal IP address, then you can connect only from a host in VK Cloud  a virtual machine that is located on the same subnet as the cluster.

A browser must be installed on the host to connect.

Preparatory steps

On the host from which you plan to connect to the addon web interface, make sure that you can connect to the cluster using kubectl.

Install kauthproxy on the same host if the utility is not already installed:

   Download the archive of the required version from the releases page:

      for Linux: kauthproxy_linux_....zip;
      for macOS: kauthproxy_darwin_....zip;
      for Windows: kauthproxy_windows_....zip.

   Unpack the archive.

   Place the executable file in the directory that is contained in the environment variable PATH, for example:

      at /usr/local/bin for Linux/macOS;
      at C:\ for Windows.

Connecting to the addon web interface



Kiali
Jaeger



Kiali is a web interface for working with Istio. To connect to it:

Make sure that kiali addon is installed to the cluster.
On the host, in a separate terminal session, run the command:

      kauthproxy n istiosystem https://kiali.svc

   If you selected a service name other than kiali or a namespace other than istiosystem when adding the addon, adjust the command.

   A browser will open and you will be directed to the Kiali web interface. Learn more about working with Kiali in the official documentation.


   Do not close this terminal session, otherwise access to the Kiali web interface will be lost.


Make sure that jaeger addon is installed to the cluster.
On the host, in a separate terminal session, run the command:

      kauthproxy n jaeger http://jaegerquery.svc

   If you selected a service name other than jaeger or a namespace other than jaeger when adding the addon, adjust the command.

   A browser will open and you will be directed to the Query UI web interface. The web interface is available only via HTTP.


   Do not close this terminal session, otherwise access to the web interface will be lost.
description: If an add-on is installed in the Kubernetes cluster that has a web interface, then you can connect to it using the procedure described here.

title: Creating a cluster from management console
data:
The following describes how to create a cluster from your management console. It is also possible to create a cluster with Terraform.



When installing the cluster, a service load balancer will be created.

Usage of this load balancer is charged.

Before you create a cluster

Familiarize yourself with the available resources and quotas for the region where the cluster is to be created. Different quotas may be configured for different regions.

   If you want to increase the quotas, write to technical support.

Run the cluster creation wizard:

   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   If there are no clusters in the selected project, click the Create cluster button.

      Otherwise, click the Add button.

   The Create a new Kubernetes cluster wizard will open.

1. Set the cluster configuration

Select the Kubernetes version and cluster configuration. See Kubernetes version support policy for a list of the available Kubernetes versions.

   You will not be able to select another version when going through the cluster creation wizard.

   The cluster configuration affects the default settings, which you will be able to change in the following steps. The following configurations are available:

   Dev environment
   Staging environment
   Production
   Other


   A configuration of one master node and one worker node:

   Minimum number of master nodes: one;
   Minimum disk size for the master nodes: 20 GB.

   This cluster is suitable for use in application development.


   A configuration of one master node and one worker node:

   minimum number of master nodes: one;
   minimum disk size for the master nodes: 40 GB.

   This cluster is suitable for use when testing or piloting applications.


   A configuration of multiple master nodes and one worker node:

   Minimum number of master nodes: three;
   Minimum disk size for the master nodes: 40 GB.

   Such a cluster is suitable for any task, including the routine operation of applications in a production environment.


   Configuration of your choice:

   minimum number of master nodes: one;
   Minimal size of the disk for the master nodes: 20 GB.

   Select this option to manually configure all settings for the cluster you are creating.


   For more information about cluster topologies, see Architecture.

Click the Next step button.

2. Configure the cluster

Set:

   Cluster name: must start with a letter. Can only contain lowercase Latin letters, numbers, and hyphens  as a separator.

   Cluster type:

     Standard: all cluster master nodes will be located in one availability zone. Fault tolerance is provided at the zone level.
     Regional: cluster master nodes will be located in each of the three availability zones, which allows maintaining control even if one of the zones fails. The total number of master nodes is 3 or more.

   Master node settings:

     Category of virtual machine: select the flavor of the VM. For more information, see Cloud Servers service overview.

     Virtual machine type  Master: virtual machine template for master nodes.

       Templates with highperformance CPUs are available upon request to support. See Available computing resources for details.

     Availability zone: availability zone for nodes. All three availability zones are automatically selected for a regional cluster and cannot be changed.
     Master disk type: storage type that will be used by nodes. The selected disk type affects cluster performance.


       The disk type you select affects the performance of the cluster. It is recommended to use an SSD or HighIOPS disk type for clusters that operate in a production environment or under heavy load.


     Number of Master nodes: must be an odd number. One node does not provide cluster high availability at the master node level, three nodes or more do. The numer of master nodes for the regional cluster is automatically set to 3.

       For more information about cluster topologies, see Architecture.

     Disk size on Master node: the larger the disk size, the better its performance in some disk operations.

   Network settings:

     Network: select the network and subnet where the cluster master and worker nodes will be located. If the required network and subnet are not on the list, create them.

     Use load balancer network: enable this option to use a separate subnet on the selected network for load balancers created by the cluster. If the required subnet is not on the list, create it.

       By default, the option is disabled and the load balancers use the same subnet as the cluster nodes.

     Use pod subnet: enable this option to specify the subnet that the pods will use to communicate with each other.

       By default, the pods use the 10.100.0.0./16 subnet for communication. If such a subnet already exists in the cluster network, specify a different subnet that is not part of the cluster network, to be used by the pods. This is necessary so that there is no address space overlap.

     Assign external IP: enable this option so that external IP addresses are assigned to the cluster API endpoint and the preinstalled Ingress controller (if selected in the previous step). Otherwise IP addresses will be assigned from the cluster subnet.

       By default, the option is enabled, which allows access to the cluster and the Ingress controller from the Internet.

   Miscellaneous settings:

     Trusted Docker Registry: add Docker Registry addresses to the trusted list to disable HTTPS connection check when connecting to them.

       This comes in handy if the Docker registry uses a selfsigned SSL or TLS certificate that cannot be validated by the cluster.

       See Docker documentation for more information on disabling the validation (see the description of the insecureregistries setting).

     Virtual machine key: SSH key, with which you can connect to the cluster hosts. The recommended value is No key.


       Limited scope

       This setting is only available for clusters with Kubernetes version 1.22.9 and lower.


     Enable monitoring: enable this option to install a metrics collection agent in the cluster.

       By default, the option is enabled and allows you to monitor the state of the cluster using the Cloud Monitoring service.

Click the Next step button.

3. Configure the node groups

Set the settings for the worker node group.

If necessary, add one or more workernode groups by clicking Add node group, and configure them.

If more than one worker node group is configured at this step, you can delete a node group by clicking Delete node group under the appropriate group.

Click the Create cluster button.

   This will start creating the Kubernetes cluster. This process may take a long time, depending on the size of the cluster.

What's next?

Set up the environment on the host from which you plan to connect to the cluster.
Familiarize yourself with the usage scenarios of the cluster.
Familiarize yourself with the concepts of the container service.
description: How to create a cluster from VK Cloud management console.

title: Creating a cluster with Terraform
data:
Description of how to create a cluster using Terraform is provided below. It is also possible to create a cluster via VK Cloud management console.

Readytouse examples of configuration files to create different clusters are listed in the Terraform section.



When installing the cluster, a service load balancer will be created. When you select addon NGINX Ingress Controller, a standard load balancer will be created for it.

Usage of this load balancer is charged.

Before creating cluster

Check out the available resources and quotas for the region in which you plan to create the cluster. Different quotas may be configured for different regions.

   If you want to increase the quotas, write to technical support.

Read about Terraform features in the container service.

Install Terraform and configure the environment if it is not already done.

Install the OpenStack CLI and authorize, if not already done.

Create a Terraform configuration file.


   The following steps list only the basic Terraform resource parameters you need to specify in this file. For a complete list of parameters, see Terraform provider documentation for Kubernetes cluster.


1. Prepare the necessary data sources

Determine what type of virtual machine will be used for the cluster master nodes:

   Run the command:

            openstack flavor list

      The available virtual machine types will be displayed.

   Select the required virtual machine type and write its name from the Name column.

Determine the version of Kubernetes you want to create the cluster with:

   Add the following lines to the configuration file:

            data "vkcs_kubernetes_clustertemplates" "k8stemplatelist" 

      output "k8sversionlist" 
          value  data.vkcs_kubernetes_clustertemplates.k8stemplatelist.cluster_templates.*.version
      

   Run the command:

            terraform refresh

   Run the command:

            terraform output k8sversionlist

      A list of available Kubernetes versions will be displayed.

   Select the necessary Kubernetes version and write down its version number.

Add data sources to the configuration file:

   Virtual machine template for master nodes. Example:

            data "vkcs_compute_flavor" "k8smasterflavor" 
          name  "STD326"
      

      As the name of the template, specify the name obtained earlier.

   Cluster template. Example:

            data "vkcs_kubernetes_clustertemplate" "k8stemplate" 
          version  ""
      

      As a version, specify the version number obtained earlier.

2. Describe the cluster configuration

Add the cluster resource to the configuration file:

resource "vkcs_kubernetes_cluster" "k8scluster" 
  name                 "k8scluster"
  cluster_type         ""
  cluster_template_id  data.vkcs_kubernetes_clustertemplate.k8stemplate.id
  master_flavor        data.vkcs_compute_flavor.k8smasterflavor.id
  master_count        
  cluster_node_volume_type  ""
  network_id           ""
  subnet_id            ""
  availability_zone    "

  Setting IDs explicitly
  Using data sources
  Using created resources


  If the required network and subnet already exist and you know their identifiers, specify the identifiers explicitly.

  Example:

    resource "vkcs_kubernetes_cluster" "k8scluster" 
    name                 "k8scluster"
    ...
    network_id           "sampleid4212a0909f30519275e5"
    subnet_id            "sampleid4bd6bda4f66dc7fbaa4f"
    ...
  


  If the required networks and subnets already exist, but you do not know their identifiers, specify the appropriate data sources and get the identifiers.

  Example:

    ...
  data "vkcs_networking_network" "k8snetwork" 
      name  "default"
  
  data "vkcs_networking_subnet" "k8ssubnet" 
      name  "default_subnet"
      network_id  data.vkcs_networking_network.k8snetwork.id
  
  ...
  resource "vkcs_kubernetes_cluster" "k8scluster" 
    name                 "k8scluster"
    ...
    network_id           data.vkcs_networking_network.k8snetwork.id
    subnet_id            data.vkcs_networking_subnet.k8ssubnet.id
    ...
  


  If the required network and subnet do not already exist, create them and get the IDs:

    ...
  resource "vkcs_networking_network" "k8snetwork" 
  name            "default"
  admin_state_up  "true"
  
  resource "vkcs_networking_subnet" "k8ssubnet" 
      name        "default_subnet"
      network_id  vkcs_networking_network.k8snetwork.id
      cidr        ""
  
  ...
  resource "vkcs_kubernetes_cluster" "k8scluster" 
    name                 "k8scluster"
    ...
    network_id           vkcs_networking_network.k8snetwork.id
    subnet_id            vkcs_networking_subnet.k8ssubnet.id
    ...
  


floating_ip_enabled — assign a public IP address to the API cluster:

  true — when the cluster is created, a floating IP address will be assigned to access the cluster from the Internet. To assign such an IP address, the cluster subnet with the identifier subnet_id must be connected to a router with access to the external network.
  false — the cluster will not be assigned a floating IP address.

To install addons in the cluster via Terraform, get the list of availible addons and install that you need.

3. Describe the configuration of one or more worker node groups



This is an optional step.
You can use Terraform to create a cluster of master nodes only, and add worker node groups later.



This operation is described in detail in Worker node group management.

4. Run the cluster creation procedure

Check the Terraform configuration file for correctness:

      terraform validate

Familiarize yourself with the planned changes:

      terraform plan

Apply the planned changes:

      terraform apply

   This will start creating the Kubernetes cluster. This process can take a long time, depending on the size of the cluster.

What's next?

Set up the environment on the host from which you plan to connect to the cluster.
Familiarize yourself with the usage scenarios of the cluster.
Familiarize yourself with the concepts of the container service.
description: How to create a cluster using Terraform.

title: Managing cluster
data:
Before performing any operation on a cluster from Terraform, read the information in Using Terraform.

Start or stop the cluster

Start cluster



Management console



This is a group operation: if necessary, you can start several stopped clusters at once by selecting them with checkboxes.

To start a cluster:

Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
Use the checkbox to select the necessary cluster.
Click the Launch button.
Confirm the operation.

Stop cluster



Management console



This is a group operation: if necessary, you can stop several started clusters at once by selecting them with checkboxes.

To stop a cluster:

Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
Use the checkbox to select the necessary cluster.
Click the Stop button.
Confirm the operation.

Get cluster information

Different information is available for running and stopped clusters. Terraform allows you to get only part of the information about the cluster.



Management console
Terraform



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
Click on the name of the necessary cluster. A page with information will open.

   General information about the cluster and the event log are available on the corresponding tab at the beginning of the page. Information about connecting to and managing the cluster is available on the corresponding tab at the end of the page.




Run the command:

      terraform state show vkcs_kubernetes_cluster.

Examine the available information in the output of the command.

Get props for connecting to the cluster

Available props:

kubectl configuration file;
Kubernetes Dashboard secret (it can only be obtained when the cluster is running).

The operations to get these props are described in detail in Connecting section.

Invalidate cluster key pair

When creating clusters of versions 1.22.9 and lower, you can specify a key pair to connect to the cluster hosts directly.

If the private part of the specified key pair has been compromised or lost, you can revoke the cluster key pair by performing the invalidate procedure.

The operation can only be performed when the cluster is running.



After performing this operation, the existing public keys on the cluster will be removed.





Management console



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
Click   for the required cluster and select Invalidate.
In the window that appears, perform one of the following actions:
   Upload the public part of the new key pair, if you have created it yourself;
   Create a new key pair using the service;
   Select another existing key pair.

Change virtual machine type for master nodes

This operation is described in detail in Cluster node scaling.

The operation can be performed only when the cluster is running.

Delete cluster



Management console



This is a group operation: if necessary, you can delete multiple clusters at once by selecting them using the checkboxes.

To delete a cluster:

Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
Perform one of the actions for the required cluster:
   Select the cluster using the checkbox, then click Delete.
   Click   for the cluster and select Delete Cluster.
In the window that appears:
   Select the option if you want to delete the cluster along with its disks.
   Click the Delete cluster button.
description: This section describes the operations that can be used to manage a Kubernetes cluster. Each operation is accompanied by step-by-step instructions.

title: Managing worker node group
data:
Before performing any operation on a cluster from Terraform, read the information in Using Terraform.

Add worker node group



Management console
Terraform



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
Click   for the required cluster and select Add node group.
Set settings for the node group.
Click the Add node group button.




Determine what types of virtual machines will be used for the cluster node group:

   Run the command:

            openstack flavor list

      The available virtual machine types will be displayed.

   Select the necessary virtual machine types and write their names from the Name column.

Add the vkcs_kubernetes_node_group resource and the necessary data sources to the Terraform configuration file:

      ...

Already described cluster configuration
   resource "vkcs_kubernetes_cluster" "k8scluster"  ... 

   ...

New data source: virtual machine type for the nodes
   data "vkcs_compute_flavor" "k8snodegroupflavor" 
    name  ""
   

New resource: worker node group
   resource "vkcs_kubernetes_node_group" "k8snodegroup" 
     name  "k8snodegroup"
     node_count 
     cluster_id  vkcs_kubernetes_cluster.k8scluster.id
     flavor_id  data.vkcs_compute_flavor.k8snodegroupflavor.id
   

   If necessary, specify additional settings given in the resource documentation.

Check correctness of the Terraform configuration file:

      terraform validate

Familiarize yourself with the planned changes:

      terraform plan

Apply the planned changes:

      terraform apply


Customize scaling options

You can change the size of a group of worker nodes manually or configure auto scaling.

These operations are described in detail in Scaling cluster nodes section.

Customise labels and taints



Configure taints with caution if the node already hosts a workload.

Reconfiguring taints can cause pods to be evicted to other nodes. If they do not have enough resources to host the pods, it can lead to partial or complete inaccessibility of applications that use the pods.



Labels and taints can be set both with the interfaces supported by the VK Cloud platform (management console and Terraform) and with kubectl. When assigning labels and taints, keep in mind that labels and taints set via the platform interfaces are periodically synchronized with the Kubernetes cluster (in one direction only). During synchronization, labels and taints set with the platform will overwrite labels and taints that were set with kubectl if their keys match. Other labels and taints that were set with kubectl and were not overwritten by values from the platform are valid in the cluster, but are not displayed, e.g. in the Terraform state or management console.



Management console
Terraform



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
Locate the necessary cluster and node group.
Click   for the required node group and select Labels and Taints.
Do the necessary actions.

   Manage labels:
     Add a new label as a key/value pair.
     Change the key or value of the existing label.
     Delete existing label.

   Manage taints:
     Add a new taint by specifying its effect and label as a key/value pair.
     Modify existing taint.
     Delete existing taint.




Change the necessary vkcs_kubernetes_node_group resource in the Terraform configuration file:

      ...

Already described worker node group configuration
   resource "vkcs_kubernetes_node_group" "k8snodegroup" 
     name  "k8snodegroup"

     ...

Labels

Existing label
     labels 
        key  "my_awesome_value"
        value  "my_another_awesome_value"
     

New label
     labels 
        key  ""
        value  ""
     

Taints

Existing taint
     taints 
        key  "taint_key_1"
        value  "taint_value_1"
        effect  "PreferNoSchedule"
     

New taint
     taints 
        key  ""
        value  ""
        effect  ""
     

     ...
   

   ...

   If necessary, change or delete existing labels and taints.

   If the labels and taints blocks do not already exist, create the corresponding blocks.

Check correctness of the Terraform configuration file:

      terraform validate

Familiarize yourself with the planned changes:

      terraform plan

Apply the planned changes:

      terraform apply


See Labels and taints for details.

Configure update settings

To increase update speed, the container service updates multiple nodes in a group at once. To keep your applications and services available during the update, specify the maximum percentage of unavailable nodes for the node group before updating cluster.



Management console
Terraform



Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
Locate the necessary cluster and node group.
Click   for the required node group and select Node update.
Specify the necessary percentage.
Click the Save changes button.




Add or change the max_node_unavailable parameter for the necessary vkcs_kubernetes_node_group resource in the Terraform configuration file:

      ...

Already described cluster node group configuration
   resource "vkcs_kubernetes_node_group" "k8snodegroup" 
     name  "k8snodegroup"

     ...

Percentage of nodes that may be unavailable
     max_node_unavailable 
   

   ...

Check correctness of the Terraform configuration file:

      terraform validate

Familiarize yourself with the planned changes:

      terraform plan

Apply the planned changes:

      terraform apply


More details about the update procedure in Cluster version update.

Delete node group

This operation can only be performed when the cluster is running.

The single cluster node group cannot be deleted from the management console. However, you can do it with Terraform.



Management console
Terraform

title: Managing cluster resources
data:
It is possible to manage Kubernetes resources in Kubernetes cluster via VK Cloud management console web interface. This functionality serves as alternative to kubectl and Kubernetes Dashboard.

Viewing information about cluster resources

Go to VK Cloud management console.
Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
Click on the name of the required cluster.
Go to the Cluster resources tab.

   All the cluster's Kubernetes resources are listed here. They are grouped into Sections.

Select the section from the dropdown list and click on the necessary category.

Additionally it is possible to:

View the resources' data by clicking the corresponding element in the Data parameter.

Specify a search request in the Search field.

  The entered search request is saved when moving between the sections.

Filter resources by Namespaces.

  The filter is saved when moving between the sections.

  Some Kubernetes resources can not be filtered by the namespace filter. See the information in the list of available resources below.

title: Capsule
data:
heading(Installing addon)idinstalling_addon

Several installation options are available for the addon.

Take into account the total maximum system requirements of addons that will be placed on groups of worker nodes. If necessary, perform manual scaling groups of worker nodes or set up automatic scaling before installation.



Standard installation
Installation on dedicated worker nodes
Quick installation



Install the addon:

   Management console
   Terraform


    Go to VK Cloud management console.
    Select the project where the needed cluster is located.
    Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
    Click on the name of the cluster.
    Go to the Addons tab.
    If there are already installed addons in the cluster, click the Add addon button.
    Click the Install button on the capsule addon card.
    Select the needed addon version from the dropdown list.
    Click the Install addon button.
    Edit if necessary:

      selected version
      application name
      namespace where the addon will be installed
      addon settings code


        An incorrectly specified settings code can lead to errors during installation or the addon is inoperable.


   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.


   Install Terraform and configure the environment if it is not already done.
   Add to your Terraform configuration files that describe the cluster:

      The vkcs_kubernetes_addon resource.
      The vkcs_kubernetes_addon data source.
      The vkcs_kubernetes_addons data source.

      If necessary, adapt the usage examples given for resource and data sources to your task and Terraform configuration (see the links above).

   Make sure the configuration files are correct and contain the necessary changes:

            terraform validate && terraform plan

   Apply the changes:

            terraform apply


(Optional) Check out the official Capsule documentation on working with the addon.




Prepare a dedicated group of worker nodes to install the addon, if it has not already been done:

   Management console


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Find the cluster you need in the list.
   Make sure that the cluster has a dedicated group of worker nodes that will host addons.

      If there is no such group — add it.

   Customise for this node group, if it hasn't already been done:

      Kubernetes labels: key addonNodes, value dedicated.
      Node taints: effect NoSchedule, key addonNodes, value dedicated.


Install the addon:

   Management console
   Terraform


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Click on the name of the required cluster.
   Go to Addons tab.
   If there are already installed addons in the cluster, click on the Add addon button.
   Click the Install button on the capsule addon card.
   Выберите нужную версию аддона из выпадающего списка.
   Нажмите кнопку Установить аддон.
   Select the necessary addon version from the dropdown list.
   Click the Install addon button.
   Edit if necessary:

      selected version
      application name
      the name of the namespace where the addon will be installed
      addon settings code

   Set the necessary tolerations and nodeSelector in the addon setup code:

      Tolerations
      nodeSelector


            tolerations:
        key: "addonNodes"
          operator: "Equal"
          value: "dedicated"
          effect: "NoSchedule"

      Set this toleration for the tolerations field.


            nodeSelector:
        addonNodes: dedicated

      Set this selector for the nodeSelector field.


      An incorrectly specified settings code can lead to errors during installation or the addon is inoperable.


   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.


   Install Terraform and configure the environment if it is not already done.
   Add to your Terraform configuration files that describe the cluster:

      The vkcs_kubernetes_addon resource.
      The vkcs_kubernetes_addon data source.
      The vkcs_kubernetes_addons data source.

      If necessary, adapt the usage examples given for resource and data sources to your task and Terraform configuration (see the links above).

   Make sure the configuration files are correct and contain the necessary changes:

            terraform validate && terraform plan

   Apply the changes:

            terraform apply


(Optional) Check out the official Capsule documentation on working with the addon.






Editing the addon settings code is not supported during the quick installation.

If this is not suitable for you, perform a standard installation or installation on dedicated worker nodes.

   Management console
   Terraform

   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Click on the name of the required cluster.
   Go to Addons tab.
   If there are already installed addons in the cluster, click on the Add addon button.
   Click the Install button on the capsule addon card.
   Select the necessary addon version from the dropdown list.
   Click the Install addon button.
   Edit if necessary:

      selected version
      application name
      the name of the namespace where the addon will be installed

   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.


   Install Terraform and configure the environment if it is not already done.
   Add to your Terraform configuration files that describe the cluster:

      The vkcs_kubernetes_addon resource.
      The vkcs_kubernetes_addon data source.
      The vkcs_kubernetes_addons data source.

      If necessary, adapt the usage examples given for resource and data sources to your task and Terraform configuration (see the links above).

   Make sure the configuration files are correct and contain the necessary changes:

            terraform validate && terraform plan

   Apply the changes:

            terraform apply


(Optional) Check out the official Capsule documentation on working with the addon.

heading(Editing addon settings code during installation)idediting_addon_settings_code_during_installation

Editing the addon code is applicable for standard installation and installation on dedicated worker nodes.

The full addon setup code along with the description of the fields is available on GitHub.



Do not delete the podAnnotations.timestamp fields or the values set in them. These fields are required for correct installation and operation of the addon.



After editing the addon code continue installing the addon.

title: Docker Registry
data:
Preparatory steps

Create in the object storage bucket, which will be used to store Docker images.

   When creating, select:

   Storage class: Hotbox.
   Default ACL: private.

   Write down the bucket's name.

Add a key to access this bucket:

   Management console


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project.
   Go to Object storage → Buckets.
   Click on the name of the created bucket.
   Go to Keys tab.
   Click the Add key button.
   Specify any key name.
   Leave the other settings unchanged.
   Click the Create button.


   Write down the values Access Key ID and Secret Key.

Create an encrypted login/password pair for authorization in the Docker registry by running the command:

      docker run entrypoint htpasswd registry:2.7.0 Bbn

   Write down the output of the command (in the format :).

Add floating IP or find an existing unbound floating IP address.

   Write down this IP address. It will be used to access the Docker registry.

heading(Installing addon)idinstalling_addon



When installing the addon, standard load balancers will be created for them.

Usage of this load balancer is charged.



Several installation options are available for the addon:

standard installation;
installation on dedicated worker nodes.

Take into account the total maximum system requirements of addons that will be placed on groups of worker nodes. If necessary, perform manual scaling groups of worker nodes or set up automatic scaling before installation.



Standard installation
Installation on dedicated worker nodes



Install the addon:

   Management console
   Terraform


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Click on the name of the required cluster.
   Go to Addons tab.
   If there are already installed addons in the cluster, click on the Add addon button.
   Click the Install addon button on the dockerregistry addon card.
   Edit if necessary:

      application name;
      the name of the namespace where the addon will be installed.

   Edit the addon settings code.


      An incorrectly specified settings code can lead to errors during installation or the addon is inoperable.


   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.


   Install Terraform and configure the environment if it is not already done.
   Create a Terraform configuration file with data about the addon being installed in the vkcs_kubernetes_addon block:

      Get list of addons available for installation.
      Get the addon settings from the configuration_values parameter using the data source vcs_kubernetes_addon.
      (Optional) To dynamically change the addon parameters (for example, via CI), add the addon settings to a separate yaml file. Use the templatefile function to add the required values.

         Example of specifying an addon

                  resource "vkcs_kubernetes_addon" "dockerregistry" 
            cluster_id  vkcs_kubernetes_cluster.k8scluster.id
            addon_id  data.vkcs_kubernetes_addon.dockerregistry.id
            namespace  "kubesystem"
            configuration_values  templatefile("./dockerregistryall.yaml",htpasswd  "", accessKey  "", secretKey  "", loadBalancerIP  "")

            depends_on  
               vkcs_kubernetes_node_group.default_ng
            
         


   Check the Terraform configuration file for correctness:

            terraform validate

   Check out the planned changes:

            terraform plan

   Apply the changes:

            terraform apply


Get the data to access the registry.

   Customise for this node group, if it hasn't already been done:

      Kubernetes labels: key addonNodes, value dedicated.
      Node taints: effect NoSchedule, key addonNodes, value dedicated.

   Management console
   Terraform

   Click the Install addon button on the dockerregistry addon card.
   Edit if necessary:

      application name;
      the name of the namespace where the addon will be installed.

   Edit the addon settings code.

   Set the necessary tolerations and nodeSelector in the addon settings code:

      Tolerations
      nodeSelector


            tolerations:
        key: "addonNodes"
          operator: "Equal"
          value: "dedicated"
          effect: "NoSchedule"

      Set this exception for the tolerations field.


            nodeSelector:
        addonNodes: dedicated

      Set this selector for the nodeSelector field.


      An incorrectly specified settings code can lead to errors during installation or the addon is inoperable.


   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.


   Use the instructions from the standard addon installation. In the addon settings, set the necessary exceptions (tolerations) and node selectors (nodeSelector).


Get the data to access the registry.

heading(Editing addon settings code during installation)idediting_addon_settings_code_during_installation



When editing the addon settings code, use the information obtained earlier.
The full addon settings code along with the description of the fields is available on GitHub.



Specify:

Details for authorization in the Docker registry:

      secrets:
     htpasswd: ":"

Details for accessing the bucket for storing Docker images:

      secrets:
     s3:
       secretRef: ""
       accessKey: ""
       secretKey: ""

      s3:
     bucket:

IP address for the load balancer through which access to the service will be provided:

      service:
     name: registry
     type: LoadBalancer
     loadBalancerIP:

After editing the addon code continue installing the addon.

Connecting to registry

Write down the data that was used in the addon settings code when installing it:

   Password.
   The IP address of the registry. The Docker registry URL will look like this: :5000.

Connect to Docker Registry.

data:
heading(Installing addon)idinstalling_addon

Only standard installation is available for the addon.

The addon will be installed as a DaemonSet controller on all nodes in the cluster, including master nodes.

Take into account the total maximum system requirements of addons that will be placed on groups of worker nodes. If necessary, perform manual scaling groups of worker nodes or set up automatic scaling before installation.

   Management console
   Terraform


   Go to your VK Cloud management console.
   Select the project where the required cluster is located.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
   Click the name of the cluster.
   Go to the Addons tab.
   If the cluster already has addons installed, click Add Addon.
   Click Install on the fluentbit addon card.
   Select the required addon version from the dropdown list.
   Click Install addon.
   (Optional) Edit:

      The selected version
      The application name
      The namespace where the addon will be installed

   Edit the addon settings code: in the Output section set the parameters of logs delivery to the selected service. Leave other parameters at your discretion.


        An incorrectly specified settings code can lead to errors during installation or the addon is inoperable.


   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.


   Install Terraform and configure the environment, if it is not already done.
   Add to your Terraform configuration files that describe the cluster the following resource and data sources:

      The vkcs_kubernetes_addon resource
      The vkcs_kubernetes_addon data source
      The vkcs_kubernetes_addons data source

      If necessary, adapt the given examples of the resource and the data sources usage to your task and Terraform configuration. For example, you can edit the addon settings code by changing the vkcs_kubernetes_addon resource.

      An incorrectly specified settings code can lead to errors during installation or the addon is inoperable.


   Make sure the configuration files are correct and contain the necessary changes:

            terraform validate && terraform plan

   Apply the changes:

            terraform apply


heading(Editing addon settings code during installation))idediting_addon_settings_code_during_installation

The full addon settings code along with the description of the fields is available:

In your management console.
In the configuration_values attribute from the vkcs_kubernetes_addon data source if Terraform is used.

Installation of the addon is impossible without editing the settings code. It is required to set the parameters of log delivery:

In the Output section of the code, set the delivery parameters to the selected service.


   Example for configuring log delivery to Elasticsearch

      outputs: 
      OUTPUT
         Name es
         Match k8s.*
         Host XX.XX.XX.XX
         Logstash_Format On
         Logstash_Prefix k8s
         Logstash_Prefix_Key $kubernetes'pod_name'
         Retry_Limit False
         TLS off

      outputs:

title: Fluent Bit for Cloud Logging (logaas-integration)
data:
Preparatory steps

Connect the Cloud Logging service to the project, if it has not been done yet. To do this, contact technical support.
heading(Installing addon)idinstalling_addon

Several installation options are available for the addon:

standard installation;
quick installation.

Regardless of the selected installation option, the addon will be installed as DaemonSet to all nodes of the cluster, including the master nodes.

Take into account the total maximum system requirements of addons that will be placed on groups of worker nodes. If necessary, perform manual scaling groups of worker nodes or set up automatic scaling before installation.



Standard installation
Quick installation



Install the addon:
   Management console
   Terraform
   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Click on the name of the required cluster.
   Go to Addons tab.
   If there are already installed addons in the cluster, click on the Add addon button.
   Click the Install addon button on the logaasintegration addon card.
   Select the required addon version from the dropdown list.
   Edit if necessary:

      the selected version;
      application name;
      the name of the namespace where the addon will be installed;
      addon settings code.
        An incorrectly specified settings code can lead to errors during installation or the addon is inoperable.
   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.
   Documentation of the Terraform provider VK Cloud contains an example of using the resource vkcs_kubernetes_addon, which describes a single addon. Data sources related to addons are also documented:

   vkcs_kubernetes_addon;
   vkcs_kubernetes_addons.

   For more information about working with the provider, see Terraform.
(Optional) View logs in the Cloud Logging service to make sure that the addon is working properly.






During quick installation, the addon settings code is not edited.

If this does not suit you, perform the standard installation.



Install the addon:
   Management console
   Terraform
   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Click on the name of the required cluster.
   Go to Addons tab.
   If there are already installed addons in the cluster, click on the Add addon button.
   Click the Install button on the logaasintegration addon card.
   Select the necessary addon version from the dropdown list.
   Click the Install addon button.
   Edit if necessary:

      selected version;
      application name;
      the name of the namespace where the addon will be installed.

   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.
   Documentation of the Terraform provider VK Cloud contains an example of using the resource vkcs_kubernetes_addon, which describes a single addon. Data sources related to addons are also documented:

   vkcs_kubernetes_addon;
   vkcs_kubernetes_addons.

   For more information about working with the provider, see Terraform.
(Optional) View logs in the Cloud Logging service to make sure that the addon is working properly.
heading(Editing addon settings code during installation)idediting_addon_settings_code_during_installation

Editing the addon code is applicable for a standard installation.

The full addon settings code along with the description of the fields is available:

in your management console;
in the configuration_values attribute from the data source vkcs_kubernetes_addon if Terraform is used.

Also on GitHub the Fluent Bit settings code is available, which serves as the basis for this addon.



Do not delete the fields that are required for the correct installation and operation of the addon, or the values specified in these fields.

There are comments in the addon settings code that allow you to find such fields.



Read more about pipeline and configuration file settings in the official documentation of Fluent Bit.
Finetuning the behavior of the addon when working with different severity levels

Before sending logs to the Cloud Logging service, the addon performs the following actions:

Determines the severity level of individual log entries. This is done using Fluent Bit parsers.
   Table of supported levels

   The levels are sorted in ascending order of severity.
    Level  The numerical equivalent  Decoding                     
         
    DEBUG  4                    Debugging messages            
    INFO   3                    Informational messages        
    WARN   2                    Warning messages       
    ERROR  1                    Error messages            
    FATAL  0                    Critical error messages 
Adds additional metadata to the logs, which makes it easier to work with Cloud Containers cluster logs (for example, searching for the necessary logs in Cloud Logging). Special Fluent Bit filters are used for this, written in Lua. This metadata contains, among other things, the severity level of logged events.
   Learn more about metadata for determining the source of logs

   For each log entry, identifiers are set that allow you to determine the source of logs when using Cloud Logging:

   Resource group ID (groupid): the name of the cluster.
   The resource ID (streamid) in one of the formats:

     For kubelet component: ..

       Example:

       `text
       myclusternode0.kubelet.service
       `

     For pod: ..

       First, the name is searched in the following labels:

       app.kubernetes.io/instance (more about label);
       app.kubernetes.io/name (more about label);
       app;
       k8sapp.

       If there are no such labels, then the name of the pod is used.

       Example:

       Let:

       In the namespace kubesystem there is a pod named kubecontrollermanagermyclustermaster0.
       The label k8sappkubecontrollermanager is set for this pod.

       Then the resource identifier will look like:

       `text
       kubesystem.kubecontrollermanager
       `
   Learn more about other metadata with additional information about logs

   Metadata fields with additional information about the logged event are added to log entries, which allows you to search in Cloud Logging, including by log metadata:

   node_name: the name of the cluster node where the kubelet service or pod is located.
   severity: the severity level of the logged event in text form.
   severity_num: the severity level of the logged event in number form.
   All fields of the JSON message: if logs are written in JSON format, then all fields of the JSON message, except msg, are added as metadata.
You can finetune the behavior of the addon when working with severity levels using:



Custom filters
Custom patterns



Set one or more rules for custom CustomFilter filters in the addon code so that only logs with the specified minimum severity level get into Cloud Logging. These rules can be configured at the level of a specific namespace and at the level of specific pods in the namespace:


`yaml
customFilter:
  namespace:
    rules: # One rule for the namespace
      min_level:
  namespace:
    rules: # A few rules for the pods in the namespace
      podprefix:
        min_level:
      podprefix:
        min_level:
  namespace:
    rules: # A combination of namespace rules and pod rules
      min_level:
      podprefix:
        min_level:
      podprefix:
        min_level:
`

It is the prefix that is configured for the pods so that you can receive logs from several replica pods that relate to the same workload.


Examples

The only rule applies at the level of the kubesystem namespace.

   Only those logs from this namespace that have a severity level of WARN or higher (ERROR, FATAL) will get into Cloud Logging.

The only rule applies at the level of the pods that are in the default namespace, and whose names begin with the prefix testpod.

   Only those logs from these pods that have a severity level of ERROR or higher (FATAL) will get into Cloud Logging. Logs are not filtered at the default namespace level.

Several rules apply at the level of the mynamespace namespace and at the level of the examplepod prefixed pods that are located in this namespace.

   Only the listed logs will be included in Cloud Logging:

   Logs from the namespace that do not belong to pods with the prefix examplepod and have a severity level of ERROR or higher (FATAL).
   Logs from the pods with the prefix examplepod, which have a severity level of WARN or higher (ERROR, FATAL).


`yaml
customFilter:
  namespace: kubesystem
    rules:
      min_level: WARN
  namespace: default
    rules:
      podprefix: testpod
        min_level: ERROR
  namespace: mynamespace
    rules:
      min_level: ERROR
      podprefix: examplepod
        min_level: WARN
`






Set one or more rules for custom customRegexp pattern in the addon code to set the required severity level for logs bypassing the standard addon mechanisms. If part of the log entry matches the specified Lua pattern, then this record is assigned the severity level specified in the rule. If there are no matches, then the record is assigned a severity level determined using the Fluent Bit parsers. This can be useful if the automatic level detection mechanism used in the addon incorrectly determines the log level of a particular application.

These rules apply at the level of a certain namespace and at the level of certain pods in the namespace:


`yaml
customRegexp:
  namespace:
    rules:
    levels: # One rule for a namespace: setting up multiple levels
      level:
        reg_exp: ""
      level:
        reg_exp: ""
  namespace:
    rules: # Several rules for the pods in the namespace: setting up multiple levels
    podprefix:  # The first rule for pods
      levels:
      level:
        reg_exp: ""
      level:
        reg_exp: ""
    podprefix:  # The second rule for pods
      levels:
      level:
        reg_exp: ""
  namespace:
    rules:
    levels: # The first rule for a namespace is to set up multiple levels
      level:
        reg_exp: ""
      level:
        reg_exp: ""
    podprefix:  # The second rule for pods: setting up multiple levels
      levels:
      level:
        reg_exp: ""
      level:
        reg_exp: ""
`

It is the prefix that is configured for the pods so that you can receive logs from several replica pods that relate to the same workload.


Examples

The only rule applies at the level of the kubesystem namespace.

   If part of the log entry from this namespace matches the specified pattern Ww%d%d%d%d%s+, then this entry will be assigned the ERROR severity level.

The only rule applies at the level of the pods that are in the default namespace, and whose names begin with the prefix testpod.

   If a part of the log entry from these pods matches the specified pattern this is a plain text message, then this entry will be assigned the WARN severity level.

Several rules apply at the level of the mynamespace namespace and at the level of the examplepod prefixed pods that are located in this namespace.

   The severity levels will be assigned according to the following rules:

   If a part of the log record from this namespace (which does not belong to the pods with the prefix examplepod) matches the specified pattern Ww%s+, then this record will be assigned the ERROR severity level.
   If a part of the log record from the pods with the prefix examplepod matches the specified pattern Debug trace, then this record will be assigned the DEBUG severity level.

If no part of the log record matches the specified patterns, then such a record is assigned a severity level determined using Fluent Bit parsers.


`yaml
customRegexp:
  namespace: kubesystem
    rules:
    levels:
      level: ERROR
        reg_exp: "Ww%d%d%d%d%s+"
  namespace: default
    rules:
    podprefix: testpod
      levels:
      level: WARN
        reg_exp: "this is a plain text message"
  namespace: mynamespace
    rules:
    levels:
      level: ERROR
        reg_exp: "Ww%s+"
    podprefix: examplepod
      levels:
      level: DEBUG
        reg_exp: "Debug trace"
`

title: Ingress NGINX
data:
heading(Installing addon)idinstalling_addon



When installing the addon, standard load balancers will be created for them.

Usage of this load balancer is charged.



Several installation options are available for the addon.

Take into account the total maximum system requirements of addons that will be placed on groups of worker nodes. If necessary, perform manual scaling groups of worker nodes or set up automatic scaling before installation.



Standard installation
Installation on dedicated worker nodes
Quick installation



Install the addon:

   Management console
   Terraform


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Click on the name of the required cluster.
   Go to Addons tab.
   If there are already installed addons in the cluster, click on the Add addon button.
   Click the Install addon button on the ingressnginx addon card.
   Edit if necessary:

      application name;
      the name of the namespace where the addon will be installed;
      addon settings code.


        An incorrectly specified settings code can lead to errors during installation or the addon is inoperable.


   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.


   Install Terraform and configure the environment if it is not already done.
   Create a Terraform configuration file with data about the addon being installed in the vkcs_kubernetes_addon block:

      Get list of addons available for installation.
      Get the addon settings from the configuration_values parameter using the data source vcs_kubernetes_addon.
      (Optional) To dynamically change the addon parameters (for example, via CI), add the addon settings to a separate yaml file. Use the templatefile function to add the required values.

         Example of specifying an addon

                  resource "vkcs_kubernetes_addon" "kubeingress" 
            cluster_id  vkcs_kubernetes_cluster.k8scluster.id
            addon_id  data.vkcs_kubernetes_addon.kubeingress.id
            namespace  "kubeingress"
            configuration_values  templatefile("./ingressall.yaml",openstackinternalloadbalancer "false")

            depends_on  
               vkcs_kubernetes_node_group.default_ng
            
         


   Check the Terraform configuration file for correctness:

            terraform validate

   Check out the planned changes:

            terraform plan

   Apply the changes:

            terraform apply


Get the IP address of the load balancer.




Prepare a dedicated group of worker nodes to install the addon, if it has not already been done:

   Management console


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Find the cluster you need in the list.

   Make sure that the cluster has a dedicated group of worker nodes that will host addons.

      If there is no such group — add it.

   Customise for this node group, if it hasn't already been done:

      Kubernetes labels: key addonNodes, value dedicated.
      Node taints: effect NoSchedule, key addonNodes, value dedicated.


Install the addon:

   Management console
   Terraform


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Click on the name of the required cluster.
   Go to Addons tab.
   If there are already installed addons in the cluster, click the Add addon button.
   Click the Install addon button on the ingressnginx addon.
   Edit if necessary:

      application name;
      the name of the namespace where the addon will be installed;
      addon settings code.

   Set the necessary tolerations and nodeSelector in the addon settings code:

      Tolerations
      nodeSelector


            tolerations:
        key: "addonNodes"
          operator: "Equal"
          value: "dedicated"
          effect: "NoSchedule"

      Set this toleration for fields:

      controller.tolerations;
      defaultBackend.tolerations.


            nodeSelector:
        addonNodes: dedicated

      Set this selector for fields:

      controller.nodeSelector;
      defaultBackend.nodeSelector.


      An incorrectly specified settings code can lead to errors during installation or the addon is inoperable.


   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.


   Use the instructions from the standard addon installation. In the addon settings, set the necessary exceptions (tolerations) and node selectors (nodeSelector).


Get the IP address of the load balancer.






During quick installation, the addon settings code is not edited. A load balancer with a floating IP address will be created, and the Ingress controller will be accessible from the Internet.

If this does not suit you, perform a standard installation or installation on dedicated worker nodes.



Install the addon:

   Management console
   Terraform


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select project, where the cluster will be placed.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes clusters.
   Click on the name of the required cluster.
   Go to Addons tab.
   If there are already installed addons in the cluster, click the Add addon button.
   Click the Install addon button on the ingressnginx addon.
   Edit if necessary:

      application name;
      the name of the namespace where the addon will be installed;

   Click the Install addon button.

      The installation of the addon in the cluster will begin. This process can take a long time.


   Use the instructions from the standard addon installation.


Get the IP address of the load balancer.

heading(Editing addon settings code during installation)idediting_addon_settings_code_during_installation



Editing the addon code is applicable for standard installation and installation on dedicated worker nodes.
The full addon settings code along with the description of the fields is available on GitHub.

Changing the load balancer type for the Ingress controller

When installing an addon with default parameters, a load balancer with a floating IP address is created, and the Ingress controller will be accessible from the Internet.

To prevent the Ingress controller from being accessible from the Internet, specify an annotation according to which an internal load balancer will be created:

service:
  annotations:
    
      "loadbalancer.openstack.org/proxyprotocol": "true",
      "service.beta.kubernetes.io/openstackinternalloadbalancer": "true",
    

After editing the addon code continue installing the addon.

Prohibition of deleting an Ingress controller node by the Autoscaler module

The Autoscaler module automatically scales the cluster: it adds nodes when the load increases, and removes when it decreases. To prevent a module from deleting the node on which the addon is running, you need to specify a ban on deletion in the pod annotation:

controller:
  podAnnotations:
    clusterautoscaler.kubernetes.io/safetoevict: "false"

After editing the addon code continue installing the addon.

Getting the IP address of the load balancer



The following uses the service name ingressnginx and the ingressnginx namespace. If other parameters were selected when adding the addon, adjust the commands.





Kubernetes Dashboard
kubectl



Connect to the cluster using Kubernetes Dashboard.
In the dropdown list next to the left of the search bar, select a namespace ingressnginx.
Go to Service → Services.
Find in the list of services ingressnginxcontroller type LoadBalancer.

   The External Endpoints column will display the floating IP address assigned to the load balancer.




Make sure that you can connect to the cluster using kubectl.

Run the command:

      kubectl get svc ingressnginxcontroller n ingressnginx

   The EXTERNALIP column will display the floating IP address assigned to the load balancer.

As part of the addon there is Jaeger collector, which requires storage to work. As a storage backend the Jaeger addon from VK Cloud uses Elasticsearch, which is deployed in the form of several replicas.

heading(Installing addon)idinstalling_addon

Several installation options are available for the addon.

Take into account the total maximum system requirements of addons that will be placed on groups of worker nodes.

Jaeger addon system requirements depend on the selected number of Elasticsearch replicas and the cluster environment. The minimum number of replicas is two, the default is three. Their number can be changed during the standard installation or installation on dedicated worker nodes.

If necessary, perform manual scaling for groups of worker nodes or configure automatic scaling before install.

heading(Editing addon settings code during installation)idediting_addon_settings_code_during_installation

Editing the addon code is applicable for standard installation and installation on dedicated worker nodes.

The full addon settings code along with the description of the fields is available on GitHub.



Do not delete the podAnnotations.timestamp fields or the values set in them. These fields are required for correct installation and operation of the addon.

Changing the number of Elasticsearch replicas

To set the required number of replicas, change the value of the field in the addon settings code:

elasticsearch:
  replicas:

Make sure that the number of worker nodes in the cluster is not less than the selected number of replicas.

Changing Elasticsearch storage settings

Elasticsearch replicas are hosted on the worker nodes of the cluster and use persistent volumes as a storage. By default, these persistent volumes are located in the same availability zone in which the cluster's master nodes are located. If the cluster worker nodes and persistent volumes are located in different availability zones, then replicas on these nodes will not be able to work with volumes.

To ensure that persistent volumes work with Elasticsearch replicas, set the storage class, the availability zone of which coincides with the availability zone of worker nodes:

elasticsearch:
  volumeClaimTemplate:
    accessModes:
    ReadWriteOnce
    storageClassName: ""

After editing the addon code continue installing the addon.

kubectl

   Linux (bash)/macOS (zsh)


      $ENCODED  kubectl n prometheusmonitoring get secret kubeprometheusstackgrafana o jsonpath'.data.adminpassword'; `
   System.Text.Encoding::Utf8.GetString(System.Convert::FromBase64String($ENCODED))  WriteOutput


      kubectl n prometheusmonitoring get secret kubeprometheusstackgrafana o jsonpath'.data.adminpassword'  base64 decode

If the addon was installed without specifying a temporary password, the password value for entering the Grafana web interface can be obtained from the Kubernetes secret. If this secret has been lost, you can reset the password to access Grafana again.



Further the kubeprometheusstack service name and the prometheusmonitoring namespace are used. If other parameters have been selected when adding the addon, modify the commands accordingly.

title: Scaling cluster
data:
You can perform Cloud Containers cluster scaling manually or set up automatic scaling to adapt the cluster to the changing needs of workloads.

Vertical scaling

This type of scaling is applicable for master nodes and groups of worker nodes. During the scaling process, virtual machine templates are changed for cluster nodes, the number of nodes remains the same. If you need to change the number of worker nodes in a group, perform horizontal scaling

heading(Scaling of master nodes)idscale_master_nodes

Learn how the vertical scaling mechanism works.

Make sure that there are enough quotas for scaling.

Perform the scaling.


   During the scaling process, the virtual machines hosting the master nodes will be restarted sequentially.

   If the cluster contains one master node, then the Kubernetes API will be unavailable during scaling.

   Management console
   Terraform


   Go to VK Cloud management console.
   Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.
   Make sure that cluster needed is running.
   Click   for the required cluster and select Change type of master virtual machine.
   Select the required VM template from the dropdown list.


      Templates with highperformance CPUs are available upon request to support. To take advantage of these templates, select the "Show high performance CPUs only" option.

      See Available computing resources for details.


   Click the Save button.


   Make sure that OpenStack client is installed and authenticate to the project.

   Install Terraform and configure the environment if it is not already done.

   Make sure that cluster needed is running.

   Determine a new virtual machine type to be used for the cluster master nodes:

      Run the command:

                  openstack flavor list

         The available virtual machine types will be displayed.

      Select the required virtual machine type and write its name from the Name column.

   Change the vkcs_compute_flavor data source in the Terraform configuration file:

Already existing data source with virtual machine type for the cluster
      data "vkcs_compute_flavor" "k8smasterflavor" 
         name  ""
      

Already described cluster configuration
      resource "vkcs_kubernetes_cluster" "k8scluster" 
         name                 "k8scluster"
         master_flavor        data.vkcs_compute_flavor.k8smasterflavor.id
        ...

      

   Check correctness of the Terraform configuration file:

            terraform validate

   Familiarize yourself with the planned changes:

            terraform plan

   Apply the planned changes:

            terraform apply


heading(Scaling groups of worker nodes)idscale_worker_nodes

Learn how the vertical scaling mechanism works.

Prepare to scale:

   Make sure that there are enough quotas for scaling.
   If you plan to reduce the amount of computing resources, then make sure that the total amount of resources in the worker node group will be enough to accommodate the workload.
   Make sure that replication is configured for the workload and replicas are distributed across multiple worker nodes from the node group.

      If there is only one worker node in the node group, increase the number of nodes in the group and configure replication if possible.

Perform the scaling.


   During the scaling process, the virtual machines hosting the worker nodes will be restarted sequentially.

   Workloads for which replication has not been configured will not be available during scaling.

   Management console
   Terraform

   Select the project where the necessary cluster is located.
   Go to Containers → Kubernetes Clusters.

                  openstack flavor list

An existing data source with a VM type for a group of worker nodes
